contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Type: Seven-passenger, front-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Base price: $43,395 (including destination charge)
This car: $54,690 (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 265 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic with manual shift mode
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/27 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Power rear liftgate
Options I can’t live without: Backup collision intervention, blind spot and lane departure warning, intelligent cruise control (part of Technology package, $2,800)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, heated front seats
Notable options on this model: Navigation, eight-inch touchscreen, Around View monitor with moving object detection and front and rear sonar (part of Premium Plus package, $3,000)
You might also be considering: 2015 Acura MDX ($43,685), 2015 Audi Q7 ($48,300), 2015 Buick Enclave ($39,050), 2015 Lincoln MKT ($43,210) (prices include destination charges)
The Infiniti QX60 3.5 looks like a big SUV (it’s actually mid-size), but it is surprisingly easy to drive and to live with, for a three-row crossover.

It helps that the QX60 has just a ton more style than cars of this ilk. The side profile is quite lovely, and both front and rear views aren’t the locomotives we’ve become used to seeing. And it helps that the interior is a beautifully, thoughtfully trimmed luxury palace, even without the $11,000-plus in options, which took our test car from a base price of $43,395 to $54,690.

In addition to the standard features you would expect (heated front seats, a good audio system, all of the necessary ports and jacks for your electronics, and a full complement of front, side, and curtain airbags), you’ll be pleased to find leather-appointed seats, a power sliding and tilting glass moonroof, and Bluetooth hands-free phone system.
The interior is a beautifully, thoughtfully trimmed luxury palace, even without the $11,000-plus in options on our test vehicle.

Drivers of smaller stature (and I with my Demolition Derby-damaged neck) will especially appreciate the standard power tilting and telescoping steering column, the power rear liftgate, and a rearview monitor which, together, make the QX60 less daunting. All part of the price of entry.

Options? Oh, buddy, are there options! You are on your own there, but bring your checkbook. The Deluxe Touring package is $3,450 (it’s where you find the air-conditioned front seats and the power-up folding third row). The Premium package is $1,550, and that’s where my beloved heated steering wheel lives. There is also the Premium Plus package ($3,000) with the magic AroundView Monitor with its moving object detection and front and rear sonar. You can sort it and your budget out on Infiniti’s online configurator.

Our test car had all of that razzmatazz and, frankly, I liked it, yes I did. But the only must-have in my book is the Technology package ($2,800). That’s where most all of the advanced safety resides, those technologies that are the precursors to fully autonomous cars: full-speed-range intelligent cruise control, lane departure warning and prevention, blind spot warning and intervention, intelligent brake assist with forward collision warning, and backup collision intervention. You’ll notice that most of these are more than warnings and alerts; they actually intervene when you’re just not cutting it behind the wheel.
And isn’t that what autonomous cars are all about?

You’ll still be doing the driving in the 2015 QX60, so it’s good to know that the 3.5-liter V-6 produces 265 horsepower—not a barnstormer off the line, but it will take you easily to 80 mph. It has a continuously variable automatic transmission (CVT), which Infiniti is very big on, and there are Standard, Sport, Snow, and Eco drive modes. The main CVT benefit is that there are no gears to mesh and gnash and make loud noises while straining to up- and downshift. CVTs do a better job of maintaining optimum engine revs. And that pretty much works. The QX60’s CVT tends to hem and haw a little at higher speeds, but probably not enough to bother most drivers. You can ameliorate it by changing the drive mode switch to Sport.
More things in life should have a Sport option.

Three-row crossovers attract a specific clientele that are not me. I have no children, I don’t have that many friends that need carting around, and the ones I have would rather walk than crawl into the wayback of an SUV.

I tested the QX60’s cargo area by bringing everything I owned and my husband’s golf clubs for an 1,100-mile trip across Florida. With mid-size utility vehicles, you have to give up cargo to get that third row of seats. We did the opposite, accessing maximum cargo space with the power liftgate and power buttons that flipped down the 50/50 split-folding third-row bench. The low load floor is a boon to women of the world with girly amounts of shoulder strength.
That third row is pretty plush, with plenty of knee room and seatbacks that recline. Getting back there is made easier by a clever forward flip of the second-row seat.

Three rollerboards went in upright, followed by the bag of clubs, four stuffed duffels, a few hatboxes, two garment bags, and, yes, more. And you could still see out the rear window from the rearview mirror. Without those clubs, we could have left 50 percent of the bench up for a passenger.

When you don’t need room for antiquing, that third row is pretty plush, with plenty of knee room and backs that recline. Getting back there is made easier by a clever forward flip of the outboard second-row seat behind the driver. This sets it up to slide forward on the same tracks that allow second-row passengers to fine tune legroom. Even cooler is the ability to leave a child seat attached in place, while accessing the third row. You won’t have to make your kids crawl in through the rear and scale the back seat from behind.

There’s an overhead handhold and an indentation in the sill to give you a boost. I gave it a go, got my six-foot frame up and through the generous opening, and was impressed. However, getting out of the third seat almost crippled me. I’d recommend calling dibs on that second row with its cushy reclining and sliding seats and its own climate controller, complete with precise temperature settings.
I, meanwhile, will stick to the driving.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: At home, you fight over the remote. In the car, the latest battleground is the thermostat. Heated seats and steering wheels are becoming common options, but the latest frontier is cooling.

This is not the best time of year to think about ventilation in our cars' seating, but summer is coming. The JKC staff has checked out ventilated seats in a range of vehicles recently, from the pricey 2015 Porsche Macan Turbo to the lean, mean, green 2015 Kia Soul EV. Those two choices prove that, once an unusual item, cooled seating is becoming more available. The cooling feature was priced as a $660 stand-alone option on the Macan (the one we tested costs a total of $97,065). It was included in the $4,420 Reserve Equipment option group on the Lincoln MKZ, which starts at $36,085; and it was on board as standard on the 2015 Kia Soul EV ($36,625 as tested).
If you’re in a temperate climate and don’t drive a lot, you may not see the benefit of this seat technology. But drivers who battle long commutes in sweltering heat will.

How do they work? you ask. With fans, in some cases: fans built into the seat to circulate cabin air. With this option, you may be able to control the fan level, but not the temperature of the air that comes out of the seat perforations. Cooled seats such as those found in the Lincoln MKZ (shown here) and Kia Optima use a thermal engine that is separate from the vehicle’s climate control system to cool the air first, then circulate it through the seatback and cushion.

If you’re in a temperate climate and don’t drive a lot, you may not see the benefit of this seat technology. But drivers who battle long commutes in sweltering heat will. They'll appreciate the cool air on their back and how it alleviates the problem of wrinkled shirts that stick to your skin like papier-mâché. And it can also be considered a safety feature.

On a 900-mile round trip in early March, JKC's Molly Jean regularly swapped temperature choices, utilizing to the full the massaging seats ("I don't want to get bedsores," she rationalized) and varying between heating or cooling the seats on a 2015 Range Rover Supercharged LWB she was driving. "You can have the heat on your feet and the cool on your rear end," she said. "Having the choice is what comfort is all about."
In other words, a relaxed driver is a more attentive driver and therefore a safer driver. That assurance alone should help sell ventilated seats to more customers in the future.

pageElements.text: When you drive up to your neighborhood car wash, you’re likely to be confronted by a blizzard of price points and option choices. Do you spring for them or just get the basic hose-off? Here are our recommendations for two options to go for and two to skip.

Two to Consider:

1. Undercarriage Flush or Wash

Especially after a long brutal winter where rock salt in the northern states and salt brine in the southern states are left clinging to the undercarriage, your car is in desperate need of TLC. Eric Wulf, CEO of the International Carwash Association, reminds us, “Today’s automotive finishes do a better job at preventing visible rust and corrosion for road salts and brines, but that doesn’t help protect equipment that is exposed to the elements under your car, with the braking systems perhaps being most important.”

2. Polish and Protect

Try a foam or tri-polish treatment to give your chariot an extra boost of shine while repelling water and debris from the surface between washes. Variations on these treatments can contain combinations of a cleaning agent, conditioner, or wax. Sometimes they’re specifically formulated to blast insect carcasses. When it comes to preserving a car's like-new sparkle, the quick wash options are no substitute for an old-school hand wax, once before winter and then again in the spring.

Two to Skip:

1. Wheel Cleaning

You may see Tire Shine or Wheel Wash on the car wash menu, but to give your tires the attention they deserve you are better off cleaning them yourself. Particulates of every kind, from antifreeze and oil-laden road sludge to brake dust, settle onto your wheels and can corrode the surface over time. Because rims come in various materials, it is best to visit your local automotive store to find the appropriate product to rejuvenate your particular wheel type. That’s also a good time to pick up some tire cleaner and dressing products to transform dull tire rubber back to black brilliance every few months.

2. Rain-X and Other "Rain Shield" Products

This popular windshield product is loved by some car enthusiasts for its water shedding properties but disdained by others because of its potential for filming or streaking. A quick spray-on version at the car wash doesn’t seem like a good bet, since precise application is key to its success. Driving through a Rain-X shower is a hit-or-miss operation. Find a reputable detailer to apply it properly and skip the random (and pricey) spray job.

pageElements.text: Look back at those kids bickering in your back seat on the way to school, and enjoy them while they last. Before you know it, they’ll be asking for the keys and driving themselves to school.

The most shocking thing about that may be that you will actually hand the keys over and let your baby maneuver that fast, massive, and potentially deadly machine into the world. It may well be the hardest moment that most parents have to face. We’re not wrong to worry. Car accidents are the number-one killers of teenagers. But here are four automakers doing something to help us feel a little less stressed out over it.

1. Chevrolet: Teen Driver

To help mitigate the blind terror of standing in your kitchen hoping she survives the deadly combination of a powerful vehicle and her own youth, Chevrolet is the latest automaker to do something about that. Its new Teen Driver feature will be on the upcoming 2016 Chevrolet Malibu.

Teen Driver is a set of features that helps protect teens from themselves. It mutes the radio till kids buckle the seatbelt, automatically turns on any active safety features the car is equipped with (forward collision alert, lane departure correction, and collision avoidance technology), and allows parents to select a maximum speed between 40 and 75 mph, that, if exceeded, activates a visual warning and audible chime. Other automakers have similar technology, but Chevrolet claims the 2016 Malibu will be the first vehicle to offer up an in-car display of how teens are driving. The system will show, on the car’s infotainment screen, the maximum speed the teen driver reached, distance driven, and the number of times the active safety features were called on while the teenager was behind the wheel.
The 2016 Chevrolet Malibu's Teen Driver feature can mitigate the blind terror of hoping your kid survives the deadly combination of a powerful vehicle and her own youth.

Parental control features in cars are certainly something you want to consider when shopping for a car that your kids might eventually drive. So if you love and covet a Malibu, these technologies could make it the car for your family. But there are other cars with features that help the parents of teens keep their kids alive during this dangerous learning phase of driving. There are even a few aftermarket devices (such as the app-linked Automatic, $99) that let you add some of these features to the car you have.

2. Ford: MyKey

Ford’s MyKey technology is similar to the Malibu's, and it is already in six million Ford and Lincoln cars on the road.The features are tied to the keys. So when you hand your kids their own set of keys, the keys tell the car to mute the radio till kids buckle up, chime if kids drive too fast, block incoming calls to the car when teens are driving, and set a maximum speed for the car. MyKey also adds extra reminders to fill the tank when teens are driving.

3. Lexus: Enform Remote

The Lexus Enform Remote not only lets you lock, unlock, and start some Lexus cars from a mobile device, it lets you create a profile for your teen to set limits on speed and distance or create a curfew. If your teen drives too fast or stays out past the limits of her provisional license, the app sends a push notification to your phone. A call to the Bluetooth-enabled vehicle will rein your recalcitrant teen back in without asking them to take their hands of the wheel.

4. Hyundai: Blue Link

This host of connected features in most 2013-15 model year Hyundais allows parents to set a maximum speed or choose a geo-fenced area. If the car exceeds that speed or leaves the designated area, it will rat the teen out via text. The program will also let you set a curfew for the car that alerts teens it’s time to bring the party home.

There is nothing quite as good as you sitting in the passenger’s seat for keeping a teen driver focused and following the rules, but sometimes you have to let them drive alone. For those times, putting a little technological ear (or a virtual eye) in the car can be almost as good as being there.

pageElements.text: Lincoln revealed its New York Auto Show concept—a full-size luxury car—to a small group of journalists on Sunday evening in New York City. The Continental Concept drew rare applause from the typically stoic auto writers when it made its debut appearance.
The first shock was the Continental Concept’s show color, a deep blue called Rhapsody Blue Metallic, which chief designer David Woodhouse calls Lincoln’s “signature color.”

The side profile is sleek and unbroken, thanks to door handles that settle discreetly into the beltline and are opened with the touch of a finger. A beautiful, wide, and interesting unbroken band of chrome rings the Continental at the very bottom, anchoring the strong shape and holding the lovely quad exhaust at the rear. Who knew chrome could look this good?

The grille anchors a brand-new face for Lincoln, showcasing a raised Lincoln badge that’s surrounded by repeating aluminum Lincoln emblems. Slender taillamps stretch the full width of the rear. Headlamps are typically high-tech, just part of the suite of technologies and material that come together to accentuate Lincoln’s new “Quiet Luxury” tagline.

The interior is a hedonistic delight, with luscious leathers (including seats that adjust thirty ways and include detachable Venetian leather travel cases on the front-seat backs that smell like…leather!), a chrome work lap tray that rises from the rear seat center console (which also chills champagne), and a full SmartGlass® panorama sunroof that can block out 99 percent of UV rays with the touch of a button.

The super-duper audio system was designed by Harman Kardon’s Revel group under an exclusive ten-year deal with Lincoln. Harman Kardon claims there is more tech in this system than any automotive audio system they’ve ever developed.
The Continental Concept will be a must-see car at the show, a car that hints of Bentley and Maybach—no bad thing.
Under the hood is a twin-turbocharged, 3.0-liter EcoBoost V-6.

Lincoln also brings to bear its vast knowledge of driver assist technologies to the Continental Concept, including pre-collision assist with pedestrian detection and enhanced park assist that will parallel park as well as perpendicular park your car for you.

The Continental Concept will be a must-see car at the show, a car that hints of Bentley and Maybach—no bad thing. CEO Mark Fields coyly suggests it is “a strong indication of the production car” to come. Lincoln dealers have been desperately waiting for this, and it can’t come soon enough.

pageElements.text: April 1 is a big day for anyone who plans to shop for a 2016 model car this fall or winter. The New York Auto Show’s press preview will feature the debuts of all the brand-new models you see here, and of course, much more. Here are some to look forward to seeing in dealerships in the coming months.

1, 2016 Mercedes-AMG GLE63

The GLE-Class replaces Mercedes’ top-selling M-Class sport-utility vehicle, part of an overall renaming frenzy from the automaker. The GLE lineup is expected to be available this fall and will now include a plug-in hybrid, the GLE550e 4Matic, as well as this AMG high-performance version, the Mercedes-AMG GLE63.

2. 2016 Infiniti QX50

The luxury division of Nissan is known for cars and SUVs that are a little more beautiful and elegant than their competition. The QX50 making its debut at the New York Auto Show was previously called the EX35. The 2016 QX50 will be 3.2 inches longer, promising more interior space, and that's always a good selling point for a crossover vehicle.

3. 2016 Jaguar XF

It’s the car that traveled on a high wire across Canary Wharf in London in mid-March to get attention. Why? Well, why not? Jaguar says it combines “Jaguarness” and practicality. The aluminum-bodied sport sedan will go on sale in the fall.

4. 2016 Kia Optima

Kia’s transformation from a maker of low-end cars to a stylish player in the marketplace continues. The 2016 Optima is the mid-size car that faces off against such huge sellers as the Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, and Ford Fusion. This more spacious, more luxurious all-new model should help.

5. 2016 Nissan Maxima

After making an enticing debut in a Super Bowl commercial, the 2016 Maxima is being officially rolled out at the New York show. This is the car that used to be billed as the “four-door sports car.” Like the looks? A little too much?

6. 2016 Chevrolet Malibu

The Malibu, always a decent car that lacked style, has a tough job, competing against the Ford Fusion, Toyota Camry, Hyundai Sonata, Honda Accord, and so many other mid-size sedans that outsell it. This all-new Malibu is expected to be modernized inside and out, with more space and a more attractive appearance. We already know that it will have a new Teen Driver feature to let you monitor and set limits on your kids’ driving.

7. 2016 Lexus RX

Time flies; this mid-size luxury SUV has been on the market for seventeen years already, and the New York show will see the debut of an all-new fourth-generation model. For a few hundred extra dollars, your 2016 RX can have some of the latest active safety technology on board. The Lexus Safety System+ package will include such up-to-the-minute features as pedestrian-detecting pre-collision, automated braking to avoid collisions, lane departure alert, and dynamic radar cruise control. The RX will reach dealers by the end of the year.

8. 2016 Smart Fortwo

Don’t knock this tiny car until you’ve tried it. Part of the Mercedes-Benz family, the Smart Fortwo is a viable option for anyone looking for a true city car. This redesigned model is already out in Europe, and it’ll be available here in September. The 2016 Fortwo is still an ultra-diminutive 8.8 feet long and still has a surprisingly peppy 89-horsepower three-cylinder engine. The new model gets an even smaller turning circle of 22.8 feet from curb to curb.

You might also be considering: 2015 Dodge Durango ($31,490), 2015 Jeep Grand Cherokee ($30,990), 2015 Kia Sorento LX V6 ($29,195), 2015 Nissan Murano ($30,445), 2015 Toyota Highlander ($30,945), 2015 Volkswagen Touareg V6 Sport ($45,615)

The elements of our automotive purchase priorities change like the seasons, but there’s one—styling—that’s always near the top of the charts. There are obviously other factors—safety features, critical in family vehicles such as this one; connectivity, increasingly important to younger buyers; comfort; fuel economy; dynamics.

But if the vehicle doesn’t please the eye, the prospective buyer is unlikely to bond with it enough to make that purchase. It’s fair to say that tidy good looks made the Edge a serious player among mid-size SUVs beginning with its 2006 debut. Taut, shrink-wrapped surfaces and sporty proportions suggested competence and action-readiness, and in most ways the vehicle measured up to the image.
Inevitably, though, styling success includes an implicit challenge: where did Ford go from there? How do they make it visibly new and simultaneously preserve the athletic good looks of the original?
The 2015 Edge shows improvement in any category you care to name: chassis, powertrain, engine performance, fuel economy, handling, ride quality, interior appointments....

Here’s Ford’s answer. The 2015 Edge shows improvement in pretty much any category you care to name: chassis, powertrain, engine performance, fuel economy, handling, ride quality, interior appointments, interior noise levels, electronic gizmology, safety features.
And styling? Let’s come back to that a little later.

The 2015 Edge is new from the ground up. It's bigger, with a stiffer body, revised suspension and body for a better driving experience, and a longer wheelbase. Overall, the new Edge is 3.9 inches longer, which translates into more interior room. You notice it particularly in the amount of room for second-row passengers and the added cargo space.
Ford’s nifty no-hands rear hatch has been enhanced with a second sensor, essentially allowing it to be opened by passing a foot under either side of the rear bumper.
New to the Edge is a 2.7-liter EcoBoost V-6, adapted from the Ford F-150. With 315 horsepower and 350 pound-feet of torque, it’s the hot rod of the Edge power program.

There are three engine choices. The standard engine is a 2.0-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder, reengineered for more power (245 horsepower) and refinement. There's a 280-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6, the previous standard engine and a carryover from the previous generation, and, new to the Edge, a 2.7-liter EcoBoost V-6, adapted from the Ford F-150 pickup. With 315 horsepower and 350 pound-feet of torque, it’s the hot rod of the Edge power program and is offered only in the Sport model, the one we drove.
All three engines are paired with a six-speed automatic transmission, which includes paddle shifters. All-wheel drive is available across the board: add $1,995.

On the road, the Edge is a gratifying blend of comfort, competence, and agility, particularly in the Sport, with its firmer suspension tuning. The new steering system is a marked improvement over the previous setup, adding tactility and accuracy to the driving experience. And the added power of the 2.7 EcoBoost V-6 certainly makes the Sport version more entertaining to drive, but even the basic 2.0 turbo delivers adequate thrust.
And in addition to improved dynamics, the roomier interior is remarkably quiet at all speeds.

Like every new vehicle rolling out today, the interior of the new Edge improves in terms of material quality and tech features. There’s an impressive array of standard features in the basic SE (from $28,995)—rearview camera, respectable audio, cruise control, tilting and telescoping steering column, paddle shifters, eight airbags, active grille shutters (keeps coolant at optimum temp), torque vectoring, and eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, to hit some of the highlights. And of course, feature content increase as the trim levels advance through SEL (from $32,395), Titanium (from $36,495), and, at the top of the charts, the Sport (from $38,995).
Ford has held the line on SE pricing, but the other trim levels represent hikes—$200 for the SEL, $500 each for Titanium and Sport.

The Verdict:

Based on our brief initial hands-on, there is little to criticize about Ford’s new Edge. Styling? We all make up our own minds about this, but this new-generation Edge looks distinctly bigger, and not in an entirely good way. There’s more front overhang, and the new creases added to the sides and hood may lend a more contemporary look, but the changes have diluted the Edge’s athleticism in the process.

It was also a little disappointing to find the current MyFord Touch system is still in place, despite its unhappy track record, although it’s been modified with a row of buttons replacing the capacitative touch control. A new Sync 3 system will be in place for model year 2016, but it can’t be retrofitted to the 2015 model. If this is an essential item on your shopping list, you might want to think about waiting until the new one makes its debut.

Otherwise, the new Edge is a very appealing package. New tech features, such as park assist and inflatable seatbelts. More interior volume. Quiet operation. A comfortable, handsomely appointed interior. An extensive array of safety features, standard and optional.
But its strongest suit is dynamics. If you’re shopping in this mid-size SUV market, and you like to drive, you owe yourself some seat time in this one.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive crossover vehicle

Notable options on this model: Air suspension ($1,385), leather interior ($1,730), ventilated front seats ($660), lane keeping assist ($1,380), adaptive cruise control ($1,600), 20-inch RS Spyder design wheels ($1,650)
You might also be considering: 2015 Audi SQ5 ($53,625), 2015 BMW X3 xDrive 35i M Sport ($51,350), 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA45 AMG $49,225 (all prices include destination charges)

Porsches should have their own separate Fun-O-Meter scale because, in the greater automotive landscape, all Porsches would always rate a 10. If I was only rating Porsches, though, I’d preserve the sanctity of the Perfect 10 for the mightiest of the machines from Stuttgart, Germany—the ferocious 918 Spyder; the thrilling 911 Turbos, GT2s and GT3s; and maybe even the immensely satisfying Cayman S.
The Macan wallops the performance competition with its twin-turbo V-6; its utter gorgeousness; and its thrill-a-minute 164-mph-top-speed personality.

So here comes the new 2015 Porsche Macan Turbo, a compact crossover that just wallops the performance competition from BMW, Audi, and Mercedes-Benz with its twin-turbocharged 400-horsepower V-6; its utter gorgeousness; and its all-day thrill-a-minute 164-mph-top-speed personality, a.k.a. its utter Porscheness. All that,  and the Macan Turbo holds a dog crate in the back. I’d give it somewhere north of an 8 among Porsches, suddenly making it that much harder for other cars to achieve a 10. (Don’t ever stop trying.)

Let me try to explain. Fun is one thing, one thing I dearly love in a car, to be sure. But even I quaked at the price of our test car. A so-called “base” Macan S starts at $50,895. It, too has a twin-turbo V-6, but it’s a smaller 3.0-liter version with “only” 340 horsepower. Its performance is blistering, too, but it pales in comparison to the bigger engine. EPA fuel economy is rated at 17 city/23 highway for both, so your choice won’t be about fuel economy. The base price of the Macan Turbo? $73,295. Sharp intake of breath. (Did I say it held a dog kennel?)

What you don’t get for that eye-watering price is a rearview camera (it comes with the $1,460 park assist option) or a leather interior ($1,730). You also do not get another twenty-seven options that were so lovingly piled onto our test car, taking its as-delivered price to a staggering $97,065. Insert your own dog kennel here.

Reel it back a notch and consider these options:
—Air suspension ($1,385). Both Macans come with standard all-wheel drive, which is designed to put all that power on the pavement. The Macan Turbo also comes with active suspension management, an option on the Macan S, that permanently, actively, and continuously keeps the Macan’s suspension steady even when you’re chewing up pavement or bombing around in the dirt. The air suspension is icing on that cake.

—Torque Vectoring Plus ($1,490). Here is a direct quote from Porsche’s Macan brochure: “Sports-car makers adore corners. With our technologies, we are forever fanning the flames of the relationship.” That technology, friends, is what torque vectoring is all about. It’s brilliant engineering that helps the Macan rotate cleanly and quickly through turns, making you feel brilliant at the wheel.

—Porsche Dynamic Light System Plus ($580), which throws a high, wide tunnel of light in front of you. When a car approaches, the Macan’s brights dip until the oncoming car passes. It’s your best friend on dark nights.

So what kind of a crossover is the Macan? It’s not one that is especially friendly to adult-sized back-seat passengers. If you’re broad of beam, the narrow, high-bolstered front seats won’t like you, either. But the hatch opening is wide and tall, making it accommodating for large and oddly shaped objects. You can dial up nine inches of ground clearance via the air suspension and the off-road console button.

You may find it difficult to find that button among the dozens that line the fighter-pilot-like cockpit. Then you’ll notice that most of those little buttons are controlling seats and vents. You get used to it in a flash, and they look really cool at night.
This is not a crossover for people who go antiquing. The Macan Turbo is a crossover for your midlife crisis.

This is not a crossover for people who go antiquing. The Macan Turbo is a crossover for your midlife crisis. First, no one will realize you’re having a midlife  crisis. Second, by then, you may have enough money to afford one. The Macan goes like a beast unchained, its seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission shifts—bang, bang, bang, bang—faster than you can keep track of it, it handles like a sports car, and it stops like you hit a brick wall. You’ll forget you’re inside a crossover.
The only thing I didn’t do was take the Macan off road. It’s mud season in Michigan, and I couldn’t bear to see its gleaming white exterior sullied.

If I owned it, though, I’d be off like a shot into the back forty to look for spring peepers in the marsh and to scout the morel locations. But just as it’s a couple months too soon for either, it’s also a tad too soon for my midlife crisis.
Clearly, I need those extra months to bolster the old savings account.

Jaguar is wisely milking the James Bond appeal of its product lineup. So it's only logical that the very first look we got of the new XF is when the automaker had a stuntman drive the new XF on a high wire in London last week. Devastating good looks are what this brand is all about, after all.

Having said that, this is not a supercar but a V-6-powered luxury sedan, and it has plenty of heavyweight competition from the likes of Audi, BMW,  Mercedes-Benz, and Lexus. One way Jaguar is facing off is to cut weight and improve interior space. This all-new XF has one very significant difference: it is made of 75 percent aluminum, saving as much as 265 pounds of weight on the all-wheel-drive version. The body is shorter and lower-slung but on a two-inch-longer wheelbase to improve rear passenger comfort.

The standard and R-Sport models come with the 350-horsepower V-6, and the XF S with the 380-horsepower V-6. An optional infotainment system is new, with a 10.2-inch touchscreen (the standard screen is eight inches). You can also get a 12.3-inch instrument cluster of the type also seen on the corporate cousin Range Rover.

Among the other options are full LED headlights, a laser head-up display, configurable dynamics (first seen on the F-Type) to let you choose your personal favorite suspension, steering, engine, and transmission settings, plus an adaptive dynamics suspension system.
The new Jag goes on sale before the end of the year.

Here’s the fourth generation of a vehicle that Lexus execs have been calling “the world’s first luxury crossover SUV” since its introduction seventeen years ago.

The latest version of this hot seller features increased dimensions, more interior volume, fancier furnishings, quieter operation, new safety features, a more contemporary exterior, and an even bolder expression of the division’s so-called spindle grille—especially in the more performance-oriented F-Sport edition.
Pretty much all of the foregoing could describe a good many of the new vehicles on display at the New York Auto Show.
The 2016 RX claims one distinction that’s unique: the goose bump factor.
Lexus execs claim that the new RX has earned Mr. Toyoda’s goose bump blessing, which had to have made the engineers and product planners breathe easier.
Aside from that, specifics concerning the new RX were scarce.
It’s bigger, on a longer wheelbase, and with agility credentials capable of pleasing Mr. Toyoda, pleasing him even more in the F-Sport versions.

When it goes on sale it will be propelled by a 3.5-liter V-6, a familiar displacement in the Toyota/Lexus power inventory, expected to generate 300 horsepower, on regular fuel. The hybrid version will be an update on the gasoline/electric system common to other Toyota products. No word regarding fuel economy expectations.
There will be one transmission, an eight-speed automatic, and all-wheel drive will be on the option list.

There’s also a new Safety System Plus package that includes a pre-collision system, pedestrian detection, lane keeping assist, and dynamic radar cruise control capable of autonomous braking, available for “less than $650,” according to Lexus.
Lexus says the RX will be in showrooms at the end of the year.

To those old enough to remember, this handsome sedan seems a philosophical return to the days when Cadillacs were big, posh, powerful, and as coveted as any car in the world.
Those were the glory days, of course, and Cadillac’s prestige has long since been pre-empted by a trio of Germans, as well as a couple of upstarts from Japan.

Nevertheless, the new CT6 appears to have the other traits—big, posh, powerful—fully covered. And unlike those snooty leviathans of yesteryear, it’s reasonable to expect this new four-door to deliver dynamics that just weren’t part of the deal in the 1950s and ’60s. Not only will it dash, it’ll zig, zag, and stop with alacrity.
Cadillac boss Johan de Nysschen expects the CT6 to be the most agile among large luxury sedans.

Cadillac wasn’t ready to reveal dimensional specifics for its new rear-wheel-drive flagship, other than to say that the CT6 is bigger than the CTS sedan, but its curb weights are comparable with those of its mid-size cousin as well as those of cars like the big BMW 7 Series, flagship of the Bavarian sedan lineup.

Relatively modest mass and high chassis rigidity were achieved by employing a mix of eleven different structural materials, according to Cadillac engineering, a mix that includes thirteen different aluminum castings and 64 percent of the body panels . A stiff chassis is the prerequisite for responsive dynamics, something Cadillac will augment with its magnetic damping system, rear-wheel steering, and all-wheel drive.
Cadillac boss Johan de Nysschen expects the CT6 to be the “most agile among large luxury sedans.”

Three engines will be offered: a new twin-turbo V-6 rated for 400 horsepower, with cylinder deactivation to enhance fuel economy; a 2.0-liter turbo four-cylinder; and a normally aspirated 3.6-liter V-6. All are paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission.
The look is unmistakably Cadillac, thanks to yet another interpretation of the now familiar grille and vertically stacked headlights, a look that wears well in this bigger sedan.
The pièce de résistance is a new ultra-premium audio option that entails thirty-four speakers.

And of course there’s luxury galore. A couple examples: “extended comfort,” seats with an adjustable massage feature; touchscreen displays integrated into the front-seat backs, allowing rear-seat passengers to exploit the new Caddy’s electronic connectivity features; and, the pièce de résistance, a new ultra-premium audio option that entails thirty-four speakers. Bose established a new subdivision, Panaray, to develop the system.

No mention of the audio system’s cost, of course, and no mention of the price of the car itself. We’ll know more late this year, when production begins. The car probably won’t reach showrooms much before January 1.

2016 Mercedes-AMG GLE63

On-sale date: Late 2015

GLE is a designation that describes vehicles we’ve known as ML since Mercedes got into the SUV business back in 1977.
And AMG, as is widely known, is the Mercedes performance subsidiary devoted to making everything in the corporate inventory go faster.

The massive Mercedes G65 is an excellent example. Weighing almost three tons, and exactly as aerodynamic as a big cube of basalt, it can nevertheless sprint to 60 mph in 5.3 seconds, according to Mercedes, leaving temporary vacuums and thunderclaps in its wake. Getting the G65 (yours for just $217,000) to overcome inertia to this degree requires massive thrust, specifically 621 horsepower and 738 pound-feet of torque from a twin-turbo V-12 engine.

AMG’s new GLE twins can reach mile-a-minute speeds considerably quicker, in 4.0 seconds or even less, with less drama and, presumably, for less money. Not bad for a big vehicle with curb weights exceeding 5,300 pounds.

The GLE lineup is wide-ranging, even including a hybrid. The sportiest versions are the AMGs, which sport freshened front and rear styling. Their suspension systems have also been revised, and, of course, there’s more of that essential commodity that sets AMG products apart from their stablemates: muscle.

The ML63 AMG brought 516 horsepower to the starting line, with 550 hp available via the optional Performance package. The Mercedes-AMG 63 has 550 horsepower on tap, and the 63 S (for Sport, replacing the Performance package) has 577 horsepower—all of this from the same 5.5-liter twin-turbo V-8 engine.
As with other members of the GLE lineup, the twin-turbo V-8 is paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission.

The new AMG GLE offerings are expected to reach U.S. Mercedes showrooms this fall. Pricing was not part of the Mercedes New York auto show presentation, but the ML63 started at a little over $95,000. We predict that these new AMG creations will start a little higher.

pageElements.text: There are some things you can’t do with an app. But, as of today, diagnosing your car’s problems is no longer on that list. Openbay, an app that lets car owners obtain competing quotes from local auto repair shops, announced the launch of a new diagnostic feature called OpenbayConnect at the New York International Auto Show today.

Most vehicles manufactured in 1996 and after are equipped with an on-board diagnostic (OBD) system that activates an alert like your “Check Engine” light when a mechanical problem is detected. OpenbayConnect gathers the car’s data when you insert a compatible OBD II device, supplied by Openbay and plugged into your car’s OBD port.  This is the same port, often located behind the steering wheel, that mechanics use to diagnose vehicle problems.

OpenbayConnect accesses this diagnostic information in real time and notifies you via your smartphone account. If it’s a simple fix like “tighten your gas cap,” you can take care of it yourself. If there’s something more serious going on, Openbay’s app will send the data for that problem to participating mechanics for quotes, which you can then accept or ignore.

Rob Infantino, founder and CEO of Openbay, explains the service this way. “It all happens seamlessly. You’re driving down the road, we know who you are, your VIN, your error codes and environmental information. All that data converts to a solution. We know your thermostat failed. It’s a $35 part and a half hour of labor, and we have five shops that can do it on Thursday.”

We downloaded Openbay's app at the App Store and found there aren’t many service providers signed up yet in our town. However, Openbay has about 20,000 active service providers signed up to work with the app, mostly concentrated in major metropolitan areas such as Boston, Atlanta, Chicago, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C. Good news for you, if you’re an Uber-using, smartphone-addicted city dweller with a car you need to pay more attention to.

OpenbayConnect hasn't launched yet, but you can get on the invitation list here.

pageElements.text: This is the time of year in northern climates when the snow melts, the rains begin, and suddenly your favorite roads become obstacle courses.

Potholes are one of the few downsides to spring. All that freezing and thawing breaks up the roadway, and your car—more specifically, your car’s wheels and tires—can suffer and sustain damage, if you’re not careful. So be careful. But how?
Such a good question. Follow these guidelines, and you’ll have a better shot at avoiding damage—or recovering from it if it happens.

1. Maintain Proper Tire Pressure

Our expert friends at the Tire Rack, the one-stop tire shopping website, tell us that proper tire pressure is the one thing that can help the most if you hit a pothole. If a tire is running low on air and you hit a pothole, you’re more likely to sustain damage because the rubber can get pinched between the pothole and the edge of the wheel. If it’s overinflated, it will be more unyielding and thus, more susceptible to surface damage. So, get a tire gauge and use it—or stop off at your local service station and check the air pressure frequently.

2. Don’t Hit a Pothole in the First Place

Watch the road even more carefully than usual this time of year. Slow down enough that you have time to avoid a pothole once you’ve spotted it. Watch for bumps, broken pavement, and especially puddles that could be covering up deep potholes.
Don’t ignore something as small as a tire blister. You don’t want a blowout later, in the scorching heat of July with kids in the car or, really, anytime.

3. If You Must Hit a Pothole, Do It Slowly

Don’t swerve out of your lane, obviously, if you are suddenly confronted with a pothole. Aside from the danger of hitting a car or solid obstacle, you could end up hitting the pothole at a bad angle, potentially causing even more damage to your car.

You’re likely to do less (or, if you’re lucky, no) damage if you are moving slowly. If you are about to hit a pothole, don’t slam on your brakes: the sudden jarring can mess up your car’s alignment or do structural damage to the car.

4. Check for Tire Damage

Get in the habit of checking your tires, says Tire Rack’s Matt Edmonds. That’s especially true after you have hit a pothole. If you’ve blown a tire completely, that will be obvious, but there can be harder-to-spot issues that can lead to a blowout later, or at least will greatly reduce tire life.

Don’t just check the part of your tire you can see; stop in to your favorite repair spot and get the inside shoulder of the tire looked at, too. If there are bulges or bumps—something that looks like a blister, Edmonds says—it probably means you’ve cut the tire’s interliner, which means air can get between it and the rest of the tire. To know for sure, you have to have someone demount the tire from the wheel. If you spot a blister, mark it with chalk, because once the air has been let out of the tire, you won’t be able to see it anymore.

Don’t ignore something as small as a tire blister. As Edmonds points out, we’re all more likely to put extra loads on our vehicles during the vacation months—whether towing boats and Jet Skis or just loading up luggage for a road trip—and a tire weakened by pothole damage may not be able to stand up to that stress. You don’t want a blowout in the scorching heat of July with kids in the car or, really, anytime.

5. Look at the Rims, Too

The odds are pretty good that if you drive into a pothole with your front tire, you’ll end up driving through it with the corresponding back wheel, too. If you bend a wheel—or a pair of them—it can be expensive to replace them. Edmonds points out that you can often purchase a full set of four aftermarket replacement wheels for less money than just a couple of original equipment wheels.

6. Report Potholes to Local Authorities

Lots of city and state governments have set up hotlines, websites, and even smartphone apps to let you report potholes that need repairing. Find yours and report problems so a road crew can fix them. A pothole generally has to measure a foot in diameter for a road crew to take it seriously. Making a report is not just being a good citizen; it also gives you a little bit of control over the road conditions where you drive every day. And who doesn’t want that?

pageElements.text:
Type: Front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter four-cylinder with stop/start technology; optional turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder; hybrid model with 1.8-liter gasoline engine, two-motor drive unit, and lithium-ion battery
Transmission: Six-speed automatic (with 1.5-liter engine); eight-speed automatic (with 2.0-liter engine)
Most interesting feature: Optional front pedestrian alert with automatic braking
Potential competitors: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Toyota Camry

Chevrolet unveiled a completely redone version of its long-lived Malibu at the New York Auto Show today, one that's bigger, yet sleeker-looking. You may feel like you've been looking at Malibus forever, and you'd be right: this is the ninth generation of the sedan, which was first introduced in 1964. This one has joined the 21st century with a 4G LTE Wi-Fi hot spot standard on all models, wireless charging on upper-level models, and a strong slate of active safety features available as options.

Like its looks? Mid-size sedans are getting prettier, which is good news for people looking to buy in this most popular automotive segment. The new Malibu is longer, lower, and more like its big brother, the Impala. The wheelbase is almost four inches longer, with one result being 1.3 inches more rear legroom. I personally observed as a freakishly tall journalist in the 6'6" range clambered into the back seat and looked comfortable. This gives the Malibu a great deal more credibility as a family car.

The Malibu comes in L, LS, LT, and new Premier levels, and there’s a Malibu Hybrid set up in the same style as the automaker’s Volt, with a two-motor drive unit, lithium-ion battery, and gasoline engine. Chevrolet promises “north of 45 mpg combined” from the hybrid model.

Fuel economy is predicted at 22/32 mpg for the 2.0-liter turbo engine and 27/37 mpg for the standard 1.5-liter. That’s on par for the mid-size segment, with the comparable Fusion at 22/33 mpg, the Accord at 26/35 mpg, and the Camry at 25/35 mpg.

Forward collision alert, rear cross-traffic alert, park assist, blind spot monitoring, front pedestrian alert, and adaptive cruise control with front automatic braking are all available options. A rearview camera is standard on all but the base model. Then there's the Teen Driver feature, a monitoring setup that lets you spy on (and set limits to) your kids' driving through the infotainment screen by using a special key fob. Attention, shoppers: This kind of safety and security equipment is a very good reason to think about getting a new car these days.
You'll be able to shop for the 2016 Malibu before the end of the year.

Type: Front-wheel-drive hatchback
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 98 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual or continuously variable automatic
Most interesting feature: Forward collision alert, lane departure warning, and side blind spot alert all available as options
Potential competitors: Fiat 500, Kia Soul, Nissan Versa Note, Scion iQ

The Chevrolet Spark is maturing, and for those shopping for really, really small cars, that's a good thing. This fall, you'll be able to shop for the all-new version of this cute minicar, now with very nearly 100 horsepower and a slightly longer wheelbase. It also has a lower profile, losing 1.6 inches in overall height, which means a less boxy silhouette.

Yes, it's a cheap little car. No, it's not monastic inside. It's got Chevrolet's MyLink infotainment with a seven-inch touchscreen. As an option, you can get OnStar with 4G LTE and GM's built-in Wi-Fi hot spot.

A rearview camera is standard on all models. Even more impressive, you can get forward collision alert, lane departure warning, park assist, and side blind spot alert technology. The 2015 model was already an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick, and this one should be, too. That's a great selling point for someone looking to buy a car this small.

Chevrolet is looking to pick up sales in the youth market with all that technology, and there's reason for optimism, considering more than a million people have bought the Chevrolet Spark worldwide since it first came out in 2010.

On-sale date: Fall 2015

Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Most interesting feature: Addition of LED daytime running lights and fog lights
Potential competitors: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Porsche Macan, Volvo XC60

The Nissan luxury brand has renamed its whole lineup with Q names. (This compact crossover used to be called the EX.) Along with the new name, the 2016 QX50 receives a modern front end with LED daytime running lights and fog lights incorporated into the fascia, plus the same split mesh grille design you’ll see on other products in the lineup, like the Q50 sedan.

The wheelbase is 2.3 inches longer, adding interior space, especially for rear-seat passengers, but also with more cargo space in the back. That's a welcome change for this smallest of Infiniti crossovers. The engine remains the same: a 3.7-liter V-6 making 325 horsepower. Both rear- and all-wheel-drive versions are available, with standard leather interior and optional 360-degree camera and power-folding rear seats.
Pricing has not yet been announced, but the current model starts in the high $30,000s. The QX50 crossover will hit dealerships in the fall.

2016 Scion iA

Type: Front-wheel-drive subcompact sedan
On-sale date: September 2015
Engine: 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 106 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual (standard), six-speed automatic (optional)
Most interesting feature: That grille
Potential competitors: Fiat 500X, Ford Fiesta, Kia Soul, Nissan Versa

Established to lure younger buyers by making basic transportation not so basic, Scion has been spinning its wheels the past few years, and the iA was conceived to help this Toyota subsidiary regain some traction in the marketplace.

The new subcompact is the first sedan to wear the Scion name, although it’s not built at any of the many facilities in the vast Toyota manufacturing empire. Aside from the yawning grille, headlights, taillamps, and badges, the iA is basically a Mazda 2 sedan—same body panels, same interior, same powertrains.
The iA is due in showrooms this September, with a base price “starting in the $16,000s,” according to Scion brand vice-president Doug Murtha.

Mazda’s 1.5-liter direct injection four-cylinder will send power (106 horsepower, 103 pound-feet of torque) to the front wheels via a six-speed manual transmission standard or, optionally, with a six-speed automatic. The automatic generates the better fuel economy projections: 33 mpg city, 42 highway. The manual version is rated at 31/41 mpg.

Although 106 horsepower doesn’t sound overpowering, with curb weights in the area of 2,400 pounds, the little sedan should get off the starting line with reasonable enthusiasm.

As for making basic transportation not so basic, the new sedan’s inventory of standard features includes air conditioning, a seven-inch center touchscreen, a rearview camera, cruise control, push-button starting, forward collision alert, side mirror turn signal repeaters, and sixteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels.
And for buyers who could be concerned about the possibility of seeing their car wearing Mazda badges: no worries. The Mazda 2 sedan is not sold in the United States.

2016 Scion iM

Type: Front-wheel-drive five-door compact hatchback
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 137 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual or continuously variable automatic
Most interesting features: Leather-wrapped steering wheel; power-folding heated exterior mirrors
Potential competitors: Chevrolet Cruze, Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Mazda 3, Volkswagen Golf
The hot hatchback market has been heating up, and in its effort to revitalize sales Toyota’s Scion division will field a new player in the game—the five-door iM.
Like the iA, its co-debutante at the New York show, the iM is known by another name elsewhere. In Europe, it’s called the Auris, but unlike the Mazda-sourced iA, it’s actually manufactured by Toyota.

Snazzed up in hot-hatch outerwear for duty in Scion showrooms, the iM wears rocker panel extensions, a deeper front air dam with piano black trim, a modest wing above the rear hatch, and seventeen-inch aluminum alloy wheels wearing 225 tires.

The sporty look carries inside, where the décor is almost all black, and the list of standard features is extensive. Included are dual-zone auto air conditioning, power folding side mirrors, cruise control, leather-wrapped steering wheel, a rearview camera, a Pioneer audio system, and a seven-inch center dash touchscreen display.

But while the exterior says hot stuff, the powertrain specs suggest something a little lower on the Fahrenheit scale. Well above room temperature? Okay. Hot? Not so much. The 1.8-liter four-cylinder is rated for 138 horsepower.

There are two transmission choices: a six-speed manual or (optional) a continuously variable automatic (CVT) with seven programmed shift steps. EPA fuel economy ratings are 27 mpg city, 36 highway for the manual, 30/37 for the CVT.

The iM will roll into Scion showrooms this September with a base price of “under $20,000,”according to division boss Doug Murtha. That price is all-inclusive—no options. But there will be a load of accessories available through Scion dealers, including a selection of go-faster goodies from TRD (Toyota Racing Development).

subTitle: Behold the epic Civic.

pageElements.text: The word "concept" means different things to different automakers: dream cars never intended for production; test beds for experimental technology; styling experiments that might (or might not) appear on a future product.
But when Honda displays a concept, what you see at the show is what you’ll soon see in showrooms.

Unveiled at New York’s Javits Center, this electroluminescent green coupe is a preview of the next Honda Civic, generation ten from a nameplate dating to 1972, the company’s most enduring product and a perennial benchmark among compact cars.
Honda is typically close-mouthed about production specifics at its so-called concept debuts, and this Civic is no exception.

Here’s what we know. The tenth generation will be a little longer and a little wider than the current car, and it will be offered in the U.S. in coupe, sedan, and five-door hatchback body styles, to be rolled out sequentially, the sedan next fall, the coupe next winter, the hatchback sometime early next year, followed by the higher-performance Si version and, perhaps in 2017, the Type R, the line’s true rocket.
Available in Europe in the current Civic, the Type R will boast some 300 horsepower from a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, giving Honda a rival for the Ford Focus RS and the Volkswagen Golf R.

When the regular Civics begin their sequential appearance, there will be two engine choices—a 2.0-liter and a new 1.5-liter turbo, both four-cylinders. The standard gearbox will be a six-speed manual, the automatic option a continuously variable transmission (CVT). Power and EPA fuel economy ratings will be revealed later.
The new car will also feature an extensive suite of safety features that Honda characterizes as “class leading.”

All of the foregoing will be surrounded by sheetmetal that Honda calls “the sportiest design in brand history.” John Mendel, executive vice-president of American Honda, sums it up: “In every way, this will be an epic Civic.”
We look forward to experiencing the next chapter of this Honda epic.

pageElements.text:
Type: Front- and all-wheel-drive compact sport-utility vehicle
On-sale date: July 2015
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 164 horsepower (SE); turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 175 horsepower (Eco, Sport, Limited)
Transmission: Six-speed automatic (SE), seven-speed dual-clutch automatic (Eco, Sport, Limited)
Most interesting feature: Automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection (optional)
Potential competitors: Buick Encore, GMC Terrain, Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Mazda CX-5, Nissan Rogue, Toyota RAV4

The Hyundai Tucson is the smallest member of Hyundai’s crossover/SUV trio—8.5 inches shorter than the Santa Fe Sport—but it’s undergone a growth spurt, and smallest doesn’t mean small. Due in showrooms this July, the Tucson’s make-over adds 1.2 inches to its wheelbase, 3.0 inches to overall length, and 1.1 inches to width.

As you’d expect, this adds to cargo capacity—five more cubic feet behind the second row of seats—and of course more stretch-out legroom for rear-seat passengers. Unlike some compact crossovers, the Tucson can comfortably accommodate two large adults in the outboard rear seating positions. But like others in this size class, the center seat probably won’t make anyone very happy.

There’s a much stiffer structure under the new skin—48 percent stiffer, according to Hyundai—as well as a new engine/transmission option: a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder (175 horsepower and 195 pound-feet of torque) channeling power to the wheels via a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission.

This same combo is employed in the Hyundai Sonata and in the 2016 Kia Optima sedan. In the Tucson Sport and Limited, the EPA projects fuel economy of 25 mpg city, 30 highway with front-wheel drive, 24/28 with all-wheel drive.

The standard engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, rated for 164 horsepower and 161 pound-feet of torque, and paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA ratings are 23/31 FWD, 22/26 AWD, modest highway increases versus the current Tucson.

On the all-wheel-drive Tucson is a feature Hyundai calls Active Cornering Control. Similar to a number of stability control functions, the Hyundai system applies braking to one of the rear wheels to keep the Tucson on the correct cornering path.

Key design distinctions between the current Tucson and the new generation are a new hexagonal grille, projector beam headlamps (LED lights optional), forward-raked wheel arches, 19-inch aluminum alloy wheels, and a longer hood, thanks to windshield pillar relocation.

And as you’d expect of any new vehicle today, the 2016 Tucson ups the ante in terms of infotainment, connectivity, and passive safety features. Pricing for the new Tucson won’t be revealed until show time in the showrooms. The 2015 lineup starts at just over $22,500 and tops out at just under $29,000.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Vital Stats

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive hatchback
Base price: $34,525

Price as tested: $36,650 (Soul EV+) (prices include destination charge, but not $7,500 federal tax credit or possible state tax credits)
Engine: Electric motor and 27-kWh lithium-ion-polymer battery, 109 horsepower, 210 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: One-speed direct drive
Safety ratings: Not rated by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration or Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. But the gasoline-powered 2015 Soul is a 2015 IIHS Top Safety Pick.
Tech features: Regenerative braking, rearview camera
Options on this model: None
Fuel economy: 120 MPGe city/92 MPGe highway; 93-mile range between charges, according to the EPA.
Chief competitors: BMW i3 ($43,350, 81-mile range); Chevrolet Spark EV ($27,645, 82-mile range); Mitsubishi i-MiEV ($23,845, 62-miles range); Nissan Leaf ($29,860, 84-mile range); Volkswagen e-Golf ($36,265, 83-mile range) (prices include destination charges but not federal or state tax incentives)

Key Points

• The Kia Soul EV has very limited availability for now. Kia is currently only selling it in California but is adding Georgia, Oregon, Washington, Texas, and Hawaii later this year.
• The Soul EV retains the funky styling of the original Soul and the roomy cabin, with more rear legroom than most competitors.
• This is the first Korean EV in the U.S. market.
• It's eco-friendly: the Soul EV uses bio-based materials and has a special label from Underwriters Laboratories. The car uses biodegradable plastic and bio-fabric in cabin. That's hugely important to some consumers.

• The climate control system extends the Soul EV’s range by minimizing energy draw, with a choice of "driver only" heating or cooling. That's important in extreme weather situations.
• Two standard charge ports are located behind the grille in front.
• The battery is located beneath the floor for a lower center of gravity to improve ride and handling.
• Interestingly, there's no spare tire, to reduce weight and maximize MPGe. There is Kia roadside assistance. A tire kit is supplied, with sealant to plug punctures and a small electric air compressor to re-inflate the tire.

• When using a 240-volt outlet, the Soul EV recharges in less than five hours. When using a 120-volt outlet (standard household current), it recharges in twenty-four hours.
• Range anxiety is becoming less of a worry because of the proliferation of charging stations. But it’s nowhere near enough yet. As of early April, the Department of Energy's map shows there are 9,331 electric-charging stations in the U.S. with 23,593 charging outlets.

• Charging initiatives: Pacific Gas and Electric Company recently asked California regulators for permission to build an estimated 25,000 EV chargers at sites in northern and central California. In January, Volkswagen, BMW of North America, and ChargePoint announced a new program that will see the installation of nearly 100 DC fast chargers across both U.S. coasts.
• The goal is to have charging sites no more than 50 miles apart.
• VW is also pledging to invest $10 million in the electric-vehicle charging infrastructure here by 2016. Tesla Motors has 412 Supercharger stations in North America with 2,263 Superchargers for its Model S sedan.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: “I’m scared, Mom. I don’t know how to do this. I want to go home!”

The weekend started with my sixteen-year-old daughter, Ava, whispering these words to me as we sat down in the classroom portion of her weekend at BMW Performance Driving School. The room was full of teenagers. To me, none of them looked older or more confident than her. But she was clearly spooked.

Days later, though, I have to remind myself that’s how the weekend started. Because when it ended, I overheard her laughing with her new friends and asking, “Did you see me toss that BMW? I nailed that double lane change at 40 mph! How’d you do?”
I overheard her laughing with her new friends and asking, "Did you see me toss that BMW? I nailed that double lane change at 40 mph!"

It's astonishing what a difference it made for my daughter's confidence to have two days on a closed track under the expert tutelage of professional drivers. But not nearly as astonishing as the skills she learned. She now understands the stopping distance of a vehicle at everything from 20 to 70 miles per hour, can recover a vehicle that’s spinning out of control without herself spinning out of control, can dodge an accident on the Interstate by “tossing” the car through an escape route into another lane and back, and knows some very important things about driving safety that many adults will never know. I think, now, I might be ready, not just willing, to let her drive.

Usually these weekend BMW performance driving schools are for teenagers only. Parents are allowed—encouraged—to take an adult driving school simultaneously. In fact, the schools are scheduled to make this possible. But parents are not allowed in the room—or in the cars—with the teenagers. The instructors insist this is necessary to keep the teens focused on driving and listening to the teachers, not worrying about what Mom or Dad think.

I was allowed in because this class was a special media-only event. “If this was a normal class,” Derek Leonard, the driving instructor who was running the show and giving the lectures, told us, “I would tell the kids that when they are done with class, their parents will ask what it was like.” To the teenagers he said, “You, being teenagers, will want to say, 'Good.' Or 'Fine' or something just as irritatingly vague. So I’m giving you something to tell them right now. Are you listening? Tell them their mirrors are wrong. Because I guarantee you that they are. Everyone’s mirrors are wrong.”

These instructors, all of whom make a living driving racing cars or teaching other people to drive them, have some pet peeves about the way we mortals drive. We drive with our hands on the wrong place on the steering wheel, we drive distracted, we look in the wrong places, we brake the wrong way. They see it every day on the roads. And they are aiming to fix the world, one teenager at a time.

Why teenagers? Not only are car accidents the number-one killer of teenagers, who are the most inexperienced drivers on the road. But teenagers haven’t had time yet to learn any bad habits. So they are easy to fix.
Next up after mirrors, which, for the record, none of these teenagers will ever get wrong now: eyes.

“Look where you want the car to go!” Derek declared, chastised, shouted, whispered, and laughed. (He said it so often, he asked us to count how many times he said it.) People look behind them when they merge lanes, they look right at the thing they don’t want to hit, they look the way the car is going instead of the way they want it to go when things go wrong. This is a habit so essential to driving that Derek was driving it home by word, demonstration, and heart-pounding, visceral in-car lessons.

First the teens broke up into buddy pairs, and each pair got into a BMW 335i. Then they warmed up on a slalom to get used to the cars, get over their jitters, and get accustomed to taking direction from the instructors via in-car walkie-talkies.

Then, first things first. If you are going to go, you have to learn to stop. So the first lesson was braking. Which also included a demonstration of looking where you want the car to go. But these driving instructors do not brake the way the rest of us do. New cars have anti-lock brakes (ABS). But many adults were taught to "pump" the brakes because, before ABS, that’s what you did unless you wanted the steering to lock up. So that’s what we often teach our kids. It’s wrong. With anti-lock brakes, you need to slam that brake as hard as you possibly can to stop the car in a panic situation.

So the teens started at 20 miles per hour and practiced slamming the brakes until they could stop that thing fast enough to make their hair fly and to challenge the seatbelts. At first they were scared. Then they got determined. Then they got good at it. When they got that right, they did the same thing at 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 miles per hour.
Locking up ABS brakes at 60 mph is thrilling. And it tells you a lot about how much time you need to stop a car going that fast. After that, I doubt very much that my daughter will ever tailgate.

Next up? The skidpad. This doughnut-shaped track is built from slick pavement and doused constantly with sprinklers to keep it wet. Ava got behind the wheel of a BMW 335i, with an instructor coaching her from the passenger's seat, and drove around the circle until the instructor either pulled the e-brake or asked her to give the car a burst of gas so the car would spin out.
She got to experience a car out of control in a situation where she wouldn’t get hurt, over and over until she could master it. Every teenager should get to do that.

She had to practice over and over until she could bring the car back under control. She got to experience a car out of control in a situation where she wouldn’t get hurt, but she also got to experience it over and over until she could master it, calmly. Every teenager should get to do that. She also learned how important it is to look where you want the car to go, if you want to master this skill.

Then she was on to the water wall, where walls of water shoot randomly out of the track and the teens have to avoid it. It’s fun. It’s a game. And then they have to do it while talking on the walkie-talkie while one of the instructors asks trivia questions. This is fun, too. And when they fail to avoid the water, run off the track, or nearly kill one of the event photographers because they were looking at him instead of where they wanted the car to go (that’s another story), they can see clearly how driving distracted can get them (or someone else) killed. A much better lesson than anything else I have seen on the perils of texting while driving. “It’s not that texting is the bogeyman,” says Derek. “It’s that you are looking at your phone, not where you want the car to go.”

Before Ava attended BMW’s teen driving school, she was a tentative driver. Her lack of confidence fed my fear of giving her the keys. And it was all moot because I own a manual-transmission car, and she believed she was incapable of learning to drive that, no matter how many times I offered to teach her.
We were only there two days. But it would have taken her years of road driving to gain this much ability and belief in her own skills.

She and I had a blast at our weekend at driving school. We both made friends and learned a lot of specific driving skills. But the confidence she gained is why every teenager needs to do this. We were only there two days. But it would have taken her years of road driving to gain this much ability and the belief in her own skills.
On the way home, she asked, “Hey, when can I learn to drive your car? A stick? That sounds like fun.” And I didn’t freak out. It would be fun. She’ll be good at it.

Want to Go?

BMW Performance Driving School costs $1,295 for the full two-day course for teens. A one-day course costs $775. Students must be at least fifteen years old, with a valid learner's permit. There are courses for adults, too. They're held in Spartanburg, South Carolina, and Thermal, California (near Palm Springs).
