pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Base price: $107,920
This car: $118,751 (prices include destination charge)
Engine: Supercharged 5.0-liter V-8, 510 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 14 mpg city/19 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Navigation system with intuitive voice control
Option I can’t live without: Four-zone climate control ($3,200), Vision Assist package (includes blind spot monitor, reverse traffic detection, xenon headlamps, surround camera, $1,760)
Notable standard features on this model: Electronic air suspension with automatic load leveling; all-terrain dynamic stability control; front and rear park distance control; rearview camera; extended panoramic roof
Notable options on this model: Lane departure warning, perpendicular and parallel park, 360-degree park distance control (Driver Assistance package, $1,560); Tow package ($1,300); Meridian premium audio ($2,150); ebony headliner and leather-wrapped steering wheel ($350)
You might also be considering: 2015 Cadillac Escalade ($76,565), 2015 Lexus LX570 ($85,030), 2015 Mercedes-Benz GL63 AMG ($120,375) (prices include destination charges)

I am a member of a most fortunate generation of automotive journalists: we’re the ones who were on the ground floor of Land Rover’s official entry into the United States, in 1987. The venerable British company was represented by one vehicle, the Range Rover, for the first couple of years. But what a vehicle.
Somehow, a solitary PR man named William Baker spun that single iconoclastic off-roader—made by a company that holds a Royal Warrant as supplier to the Queen—into pure gold.

Baker created fantastical adventures for journalists in the most desolate, far-flung, and seemingly impassable places on Earth. His team invited us to learn how to fearlessly plunge these four-wheeled mountain goats blindly off the edges of cliffs, to dive into rivers that lapped the Range Rover’s hood, and to confidently set off on adventures of a lifetime. There wasn’t an enthusiast car magazine that didn’t publish at least one multipage, full-color Range Rover story every year.

Looking only at my own personal list of Range Rover stories, you’ll find wild accounts from the Great Divide, the rainforest of Belize, Iceland’s glaciers, remote rivers in Scotland, the Camel Trophy of Madagascar, and the desolate Little Karoo in the Western Cape of South Africa, where I was raced by a herd of ostriches. They won.
Not that the people buying Range Rovers in record numbers will be taking theirs anywhere at all like that. Just saying.
But it’s good to know that Range Rovers will go anywhere that four wheels and four-wheel drive can transport you, right?
Over the years, its suspension became more sophisticated, and its exterior design has morphed significantly from the tweedy luxury of the old days.

This 2015 Range Rover Supercharged Long Wheelbase (LWB) is no exception. It’s ready for virtually everything you have to throw at it, from a jaunt across the Gobi to an evening at La Scala. And after paying $118,751 for it, you really ought to consider giving it that kind of momentous assignment. The first Range Rover was a tall, narrow box that felt much better off the road than on it. Over the years, its suspension became more sophisticated, and its exterior design has morphed significantly from the tweedy luxury of the old days.

The change to the current, curvaceous aesthetic began when BMW acquired it for a minute in the 1990s. At that time, the engine became a reliable and powerful BMW, and the design and materials, both inside and outside, soared under the direction of quirky, chain-smoking chief designer Geoff Upex. When the equally quirky Gerry McGovern stepped in to the chief designer position at Land Rover, well, goodbye Wellies, hello Cristal.
Are we complaining? No, we are not. And neither would you, behind the wheel of the 2015 Range Rover.

The Range Rover Supercharged LWB, as its name declares, has a 5.0-liter, 510-horsepower supercharged V-8. It’s teamed with an eight-speed automatic transmission and paddle shifters. Punch the pedal to pass on a two-lane road, and the Range Rover immediately delivers the power in a manner that will make you think of rollercoasters. This 5,320-pound luxury liner offers a 0-to-60-mph time of 5.7 seconds, with a staggering top speed of 155 mph. No, I did not come close to 155 mph on any terrain.

Beyond sheer power, there is sheer capability. This Range Rover brings it with an electronic air suspension and auto load leveling, plus full-time all-wheel drive, plus an upgraded Terrain Response 2 auto-adaptive off-road driving system with individual settings for different types of terrain. Icing on the cake is the advertised maximum wading depth of 35.4 inches. Tempting!

The LWB model we drove extends the classic Range Rover profile with 7.8 more inches of wheelbase, 11.1 more cubic feet of cargo space in back, and 7.3 more inches of rear legroom, along with massive rear doors. Rear-seat occupants in the LWB model can stretch out like they are in business class on Virgin Atlantic.

The distinctive look of a Range Rover is part of what you’re paying for, and the automaker has wisely not diluted or changed it much over the years. Like the Royal Family it serves, the company has evolved without changing its essential personality. Yet the look is quite modern. In profile, the current Range Rover has a very defined waistline that is integrated into both the headlights (themselves worthy of a museum catalog) and the taillights.

Three shark-like vertical gills on the front doors are a graphic illusion—not functional, but very elegant. Completing the side profile view is a floating roof. That’s designer-speak for a roof that has the illusion of floating above the body. Range Rovers have been sporting this design feature for decades. The going-away view is understated, with stacked square taillights that complete the package.

The interior of the Range Rover is flawless. Aluminum accents, dark wood, and supple leather remind you that every nook and cranny has been refined to a fare-thee-well. The view through the steering wheel perfectly exposes every detail of the digital dash; no need to rock your head from side to side. The transmission shifter pops up from the center console, in the style of corporate sibling Jaguar, when you push the start button. It may sound gimmicky, but it quickly becomes effortless. The glove box is two separate compartments, both accessible via a large button. Our test car included the Four Zone Climate Comfort package ($3,200). That sounds awfully pricey, but it is actually jam-packed with desirable features: heated and cooling seats for all passengers, plus rear-seat power lumbar support and power blinds in back. Massaging seats, however, are reserved for the special derrières up front. They were more nudge than massage—useful to make a long drive less exhausting, but not quite on a level with the Brookstone massaging seats at the local mall.

This package also includes a cool box tucked into the center console, and a special windshield that helps keep the interior cooler. As the outside temperature was hovering around 30 degrees (a Michigan heat wave!), there was no need for it to actually work.

Standard fog lights are new for 2015. Our test vehicle also had adaptive xenon headlights with automatic high beam assist, part of the optional Vision Assist package. The combination of grille, headlights, and large horizontal finned vents adds up to an imposing face that commands attention.
Although there was no stream fording or mountain diving involved in our week with this Range Rover, it was a hands-down five-star experience.

Modern safety features are available, including blind spot monitoring, rear traffic detection, and a rearview camera. The options list also includes lane departure warning and parallel and perpendicular parking assist. Our test vehicle had the tow package ($1,300), premium audio ($2,150), and an ebony headliner and leather-wrapped steering wheel ($350).

Although there was no stream fording or mountain diving involved in our week with this Range Rover (not our $118,751), it was a hands-down five-star experience for the Jean Knows Cars staff. Especially notable—the Holy Grail in this category—is the large touchscreen that easily led you to your desired destination. We heard angels singing when we spied SET DESTINATION right on the home screen. It changes to CANCEL GUIDANCE, so you don’t need to dig three screens deep to make the car quit barking directions at you. Every button was perfectly placed, except the window controls that were awkwardly high on the doorsill. They’ve always been awkward in some way or another on Range Rovers. This is clearly not a deal breaker, nor is the 14 mpg city/19 mpg highway, because seriously, at this lofty price point, does mileage really matter?

The Verdict:

Do you want to go off road in style? Here’s your vehicle. Do you simply want to travel in royal comfort, with rear-seat passengers stretched out like so many house cats, at a completely effortless 80 mph on the freeway? Here’s your vehicle. The Range Rover has competitors as the luxury-SUV market grows, but it has no peer when it comes to Anglophile, old-school-tie, empire-exploring history. You may find yourself humming “Land of Hope and Glory,” and who can blame you?

When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Before testing the 2015 Ford F-150 4x2 SuperCab, I’d seldom considered the difference between extended cab and crew cab pickups, but it’s an important consideration for anyone buying a new truck.

Besides these two versions, Ford also offers a regular cab with a single seat for three people, but the typical buyer is the termite doctor or local utility companies. The rest of us want extra seating capacity and a roomier cabin. So Ford intenders must ask: SuperCab or SuperCrew?

Both seat six, but while the SuperCab has a back seat and 170-degree-opening rear access doors, the SuperCrew has four traditional doors and a spacious rear seating area with a lot of legroom and storage space. Both have four doors, but the user experience differs drastically.

As Jean established in her recent review, the new F-150 is comfy yet rugged, and the turbocharged 2.7-liter V-6—one of four available engines—has plenty of woof. I drove the 4x2 version and enjoyed a more supple ride than she reported after sampling the 4x4. With the Lariat trim level, my truck stickered at $41,070 including destination and delivery charges.
The choice between SuperCab and SuperCrew is like that between the hardcover and audio version of a book. Where and how will you devour it?
Here are some pros and (mostly) cons on the SuperCab:

1. Cargo capacity. In the SuperCab version, a 6.5-foot cargo bed is standard, and an 8.0-footer is optional. The SuperCrew has a 5.5-foot bed, and the 6.5-footer is optional. I appreciated the longer bed, which allowed me to haul an old mattress set to the dump with the tailgate closed. For all a crew cab’s wonders, the bed is often too short, and I end up driving around with the tailgate down and cargo sticking out. So, for human capacity, the SuperCrew (shown here with tan interior) is better. For cargo in the back, it's the SuperCab.

2. Entry and exit. The SuperCrew you see here has regular doors. The SuperCab has partial doors and no center pillar and grab handle, meaning there’s no way to assist yourself. On first attempt I reached up and hooked my middle two fingers through the half-door’s upper anchoring loop, but it became clear that relying on such a technique would ultimately result in dislocated digits. On my second attempt, I intrepidly vaulted over the sill but smashed my head against the loop, which I can attest is made of tempered steel. Finally, summoning my inner Olympic decathlete, I managed a hop-and-skip maneuver that resulted in a successful soft landing. The SuperCrew's doors, like those on a sedan, are user-friendly, and so is the entry-and-exit process. If you (or kids, or colleagues) are getting in and out every day, it's the hands-down choice.

3. Overall length. The SuperCab F-150 I tested had a 145.0-inch wheelbase and stretched to 231.9 inches long. With the eight-foot bed, it extended an amazing 163.7 inches in wheelbase and, at 250.5 inches, nearly two and a half Smart cars in length. The longest SuperCrew version, with the 6.5-foot bed, is 243.7 inches with a 156.5-inch wheelbase: still pretty big, though. If that idiot in the Nissan Sentra wants to tailgate, it’s his problem.

4. Door management issues. This is an issue with the SuperCab's unusual rear-opening method. Hey, even if you get the hang of it, your passengers won’t. (Think of how many people enter through the exit at Walmart.) Accidentally closing the front door before the half-door will happen. Buying the SuperCab means a commitment to personnel management, like coaching a basketball team.
Bang the front door harder! Because it fastens to the rear half-door, which is less stiff than the SuperCrew’s center pillar, more force is required in closing.

However, the shoulder harness for the driver and front outboard passenger is attached to each rear half-door. So rear passengers must be inside before belts are attached, and no one from the back can exit until the front doors open up and belts are removed.

How to Choose:

The F-150 SuperCab is for those who need cargo capacity and only occasionally carry passengers. Ford’s spokesperson says about 25 percent of buyers—an amount that’s close to 200,000 per year—will choose it. Optional running boards are a good idea. For anybody who wants to carry passengers, especially kids, on a regular basis, go for the SuperCrew and its much more traditional back seat.

More to Read:

2015 Ford F-150: Should You Buy It? by Jean Jennings

title: 8 Great Grilles
subTitle: The best front ends from the New York Auto Show.

metaDescription: The best front ends from the New York Auto Show.

pageElements.text: The 2015 New York International Auto Show is open to the public through this weekend, and automakers from around the world are there, showcasing their all-new or refreshed 2016 models.

In a sea of brightly colored cars, crossovers, and SUVs, these eight introductions stood out for their quirky, aggressive, or cute front ends. Seven of these eight choices go on sale before year’s end; the eighth, currently in concept form, is expected to become a production model soon.
Here are our favorite fascias from this year’s New York Auto Show.

1. 2016 Lexus RX

If you’re looking for a distinctive grille, Lexus is your brand. This is what Lexus, the luxury division of Toyota, calls a “spindle” grille. Too much? You can’t fault them for being too conservative. It’s an aggressive, stylish, and ultimately unforgettable front end, especially (as shown here) on the sportiest F-Sport version. The RX luxury crossover is a big seller for Lexus, and the 2016 model should be no exception. It is expected in dealerships late this fall.
More details on the RX here.

2. 2016 Cadillac CT6

Cadillac’s new flagship comes out early next year. What’s missing from the grille? The wreath that used to encircle the Cadillac crest, a modernizing touch. GM’s luxury division did away with the old-school wreath for its modern, sleek, high-performance products. It’s keeping the coat-of-arms crest, though. Those dangly-earring-style headlamps are Cadillac’s Indirect Fire LEDs.
More details on the CT6 here.

3. 2016 Infiniti QX50

The Nissan luxury brand has renamed its whole lineup with Q names. (This compact crossover used to be called the EX.) Along with the new name, the all-new QX50 has a modern front end with LED daytime running lights and fog lights incorporated into the fascia, plus the same split mesh grille design you’ll see on other products in the lineup, like the Q50 sedan. The QX50 crossover will hit dealerships in the fall.
More details on the QX50 here.

4. 2016 Kia Optima

The long, narrow “tiger nose” grille on the Kia Optima adds interest to a car in a challenging category. An economy sedan can look boring, but Kia’s signature grille and the sweeping cat-eye high-intensity-discharge (HID) headlamps looks just as good on the Optima as on the Korean automaker’s flagship, the K900. The new Optima goes on sale later this year.
More details on the Optima here.

5. Lincoln Continental Concept

The only car on this list that isn’t coming soon to the dealership from the auto show, the flagship Lincoln with the classic Lincoln name is nevertheless expected to go into production within a year or so. The grille anchors a brand-new face for Lincoln, showcasing a raised Lincoln badge that’s surrounded by repeating aluminum Lincoln emblems. The headlamps are typically high-tech, just part of the suite of technologies and material that come together to accentuate Lincoln’s new “Quiet Luxury” tagline.
More details on the Continental Concept here.

6. 2016 Scion iA

You can’t say that Toyota’s “youth” brand failed to go for the gusto when they designed this brand-new car’s front end. The iA is the first four-door sedan from the maker of sporty little cars. Its hexagonal grille swoops low, with an aggressive largemouth-bass or Dustbuster aesthetic, but it seems entirely appropriate for a fun little car in this price class. The Scion iA will be priced starting in the $16,000 range when it goes on sale in September.
More details on the iA here.

7. 2016 Smart Fortwo

It’s only 8.8 feet long, and you can spin it in a turning radius of less than 23 feet, but this second-generation city car still manages to look good without being too cutesy. It’s part of the Mercedes-Benz corporate stable, and the 2016 model is all new. The front end gets a larger Smart logo in the middle of a slightly larger honeycomb-pattern grille, plus a lower honeycomb air opening in the bumper, adding to the impression you’re looking at a friendly smiling face. The new Fortwo will be on sale this fall.
More details on the Fortwo here.

8. 2016 Nissan Maxima

The Nissan Maxima, the automaker’s top-end sedan, is advertised as the “four-door sports car,” and that reputation will be bolstered by the edgy design the Japanese automaker has adopted for the all-new 2016 model. This extreme grille ought to be a love-it-or-hate-it proposition. The headlights have a “signature line” of LED lights that are always on, and the 4DSC tagline is embossed inside the lamp housings. If you haven’t figured it out yet, enormous mesh grilles are all the rage these days. The new Maxima will be on sale in this summer.
More details on the Maxima here.

pageElements.text: Director of design Marek Reichman came to Aston Martin from Lincoln in 2005. He stepped bravely into the very large shoes of superstar designer Ian Callum, who has been a towering force at Jaguar since. Reichman quickly got his sea legs, as evidenced by the Rapide S (pictured here), one of the most beautiful cars in the world. And now, Vulcan!

Even the mildest of contemporary Aston Martin cars is hot stuff, but this one figures to be flat-out torrid—the closest thing you can get to one of the company’s Le Mans 24 Hours racing cars. The competition reference is apropos, because this limited-edition hot rod is intended strictly for track use; there's no street-legal version.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/02NWuVYJ8YY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Aston Martin Vulcan Limited edition means just that; Aston Martin plans to build just twenty-four Vulcans and sell them at a reported $2.3 million each. Does that sound steep? Consider that the price includes tuition from the Aston Martin racing operation, as well as company-sponsored track days at famous racing venues. Then, of course, there’s the car: carbon fiber chassis, carbon fiber skin, magnesium torque tube surrounding a carbon fiber driveshaft, huge carbon-ceramic brakes from Brembo. The suspension package includes racing-style in-board shock absorbers, adjustable cockpit, and adjustable anti-roll bars.
And of course there’s ample power—more than 800 horsepower, according to Aston Martin, delivering thrust to the rear wheels via a six-speed racing transmission.
Exterior finish? Interior decor? Well, what are your preferences? As is appropriate at this price point, Aston’s trim department will make sure your Vulcan is exactly as you like it

When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Do you know the Vochitos of Mexico? Even if you don't know their name, you recognize that eternal silhouette. Until 2003, Volkswagen Beetles were built in a massive plant in the city of Puebla, bringing cheap mobility to an emerging middle class.
Very much loved, they earned a nickname. “Volks” was paired with “chito,” the Spanish diminutive and term of endearment. Slightly too hard to say, it was shortened to Vochito.
Today, a trip to Mexico is Beetlemania. Vochitos are everywhere, and no two are alike. They are variously battered, patched, trimmed, shod, and crowned.

To an estadounidense—someone from the United States, especially those who came of age in the 1960s—they remind of bygone carefree times, when leaving home in your Beetle meant carrying a toothbrush, a change of underwear, and $3 for gas.

In Mexico, the Beetle has slightly different associations, although the common element is freedom. “Everyone I know has had a Vochito somewhere in their life,” travel agency owner Carlos Marquez told me. “Mexico was a developing country; it still is, but that was the right car.”
Marquez remembers his mother’s first car, a 1971 Vochito, lasting well into the 1980s. “The car was a useful tool,” he said. “It took Mom to work, and then we would maybe borrow it on Friday night.”
In fact, he learned to drive in the family’s Vochito and survived Mexico City traffic. “It’s more chaotic than you think.”
Vochitos were used as taxis and police cars and became a “cultural icon—especially for Mexico City.”

Marquez said a “point of pride” for Mexican automotive engineering in the 1980s was the addition of fuel injection to Puebla-built Vochitos, replacing a messy carburetor as the means of infusing gasoline to the combustion mixture. Next, to clean up the exhaust stream, a catalytic converter was attached.
Even after the VW Golf (known in Mexico as the Caribe) and then the New Beetle were manufactured in the same factory, the Vochito lived on in the marketplace.

Dented, dinged, and slabbed with putty, Vochitos make a feast for the eyes. Who wouldn’t want to go all around the Mexican countryside as I did, just looking for the next example and taking its picture?

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Music, phone calls, texts, and complex infotainment systems: we’ve never spent more time in our cars, nor have we been more distracted. But thankfully, technology is making advanced safety features cheaper and more accessible to help keep us out of harm's way.

The next time you’re shopping for a car, you're likely to be faced with optional driver assistance technology packages. Ten years ago, that may have been referring to an extra set of cup holders or in some brands, push-button roadside assistance to help you alert emergency services or get directions to the airport. Today, that rather polite-sounding option is really advanced safety technology that could help you avoid an accident.

Driver assistance technology refers to collision avoidance features, such as forward crash warning and avoidance, blind-spot monitoring, and lane departure warning systems. Until recently, these safety options were found only in high-end or luxury brands, but high-definition cameras are making this life-saving technologies available on a wider and more accessible range of vehicles.

Blind spot monitoring, like the setup on the 2015 Nissan Altima we used as our example, typically use either laser sensors or, more commonly, high-definition cameras to monitor the sides of the vehicles. When enabled, BPMS warns the driver using graphics or chimes or both when it detects another vehicle traveling in the same direction and in the driver’s blind spot.

The 2015 Nissan Altima uses lights embedded in the A-pillars (the left and right frame of the windshield) to alert the driver, and emits a chime only if the turn signal is on. In the week I drove the Altima, I found the feature unintrusive. So unintrusive that I barely noticed it and had to train myself to look for the lights, when really I should have just been checking my blind spot.
A survey found 71 percent of Toyota Sienna and Prius drivers equipped with blind spot monitor technology said they liked this feature and would want it in their next car.

But other drivers with blind-spot monitoring system found this feature helpful and were more apt to use their turn signals, according to an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) survey. It found that 71 percent of drivers of Toyota Prius and Siennas equipped with this technology said they liked this feature and would want it in their next car.


Is that you? Check out this handy IIHS database of crash avoidance features sorted by make and model from 2007 through 2015 model years.

Bundled in the same technology package is a lane departure warning system, which also uses cameras or radar sensors to monitor the road lane marking and alert the driver when the vehicle exits its lane without a turn signal when they are traveling above a certain speed, typically around 45 mph (may vary by manufacturer).

Although lane departure warning systems have the potential to prevent or mitigate thousands of annual fatalities that result from a vehicle leaving the roadway, accidents resulting from lane drifts are actually rare, and it’s only effective at highway speeds when lane lines are clearly marked, which means that this feature may not work as well on curvy back mountain roads or under snowy conditions.

In the week I spent testing this feature in the Nissan Altima, I kept wondering if it was even on. There is a lot of construction in my neck of the woods, which means that lane markings often aren’t clear and traffic travels too slowly for this feature to work. However, it’s like any other safety feature: good to have it for that small chance that you’ll actually need it. The IIHS hasn’t investigated if drivers are turning this feature off because of false alerts, or if lane departure equipped with lane keeping assistance (the vehicle applies small amount of steering to keep the vehicle in its original lane) is more effective.

The Verdict:

Whether you think you need it or not, there is an upside to these features. Driver assistance technology encourages drivers to use their turn signals more, according to the IIHS, which creates a ripple effect of improved traffic safety for all drivers on the road.
And even the best drivers could all use another (or a half dozen) set of eyes on the road to keep them out of harm's way.

Key Points:

• This is the so-called “Baby Cayenne.”
• It may be the perfect mid-life crisis vehicle, since driving it doesn't make it obvious that you’re having one.
• The Macan is a sought-after luxury compact crossover/SUV with its sports-car-like handling, powerful engine options, and comfortable ride.
• The name Macan is Indonesian for "tiger."

• This one has its claws out for the competition and really plays in a space that has not been served: Competitors do not offer a luxury compact crossover with 400 horsepower and those optional garnet red seatbelts.
• The Macan Turbo sprints from 0 to 60 mph in 4.6 seconds and has a top track speed of 164 mph. Perfect for a grocery run.
• There's a shocking disparity between the base price of around $50,000 for the standard model to the fully loaded one shown here, priced at nearly $100,000.
• The standard Macan is not a spartan experience due to generous standard features. Also, Porsche doesn’t make a big deal out of this, but the base model also has a twin-turbo engine as noted above.
• Standard features include a multifunction sport steering wheel with paddle shifters, nineteen-inch wheels, a high-performance audio system, and a power tailgate.
• The base Macan is intriguing, since it’s the first time the 3.6-liter twin-turbo V-6 is being used in a Porsche.

• From a design standpoint, the Macan takes some of its cues from the 918 Spyder and the 911. The Macan adopts the basic shape of the headlights from the 918 Spyder and the profile of the rear fenders from the 911.
• Our test car has the $420 Porsche Car Connect option, which lets you use your smartphone to locate your vehicle, access vehicle information, and contact Porsche in the event of a breakdown.
• The cabin has lots of buttons, but they are generally intuitive after some use.
• Test car has an optional $1,290 Sport Chrono package that adds a stopwatch with an analog and digital display to the cockpit.
• The performance display lets you view a range of driving stats, including your total driving time, current lap distance, and lap times recorded so far.
• The lateral and longitudinal forces acting on the vehicle are illustrated by the G-Force graphic on the color screen in the instrument cluster.
• Cargo space is limited.

title: 6 Ways Cameras Will Change Your Life
subTitle: Your driving life, anyway. We highlight brilliant safety and convenience features on new models.

pageElements.text:
If you don’t have cameras in your car now, you will pretty soon. Backing up without worrying about backing over a tricycle or a toddler is a great safety advance that we’ll all be taking for granted by the end of the decade. But cameras, and the radar and sensors that they work with, can do so much more to ensure our comfort and improve our driving.

Here are some of our favorites. Make sure you look for these safety features when you shop for your next car or truck.

1. Back up without fear.

Rearview cameras, also known as “backup cameras,” will be required equipment on all new vehicles built after May 2018. They’re already appearing as standard on a large variety of cars, even very low-priced ones such as the 2015 Toyota Corolla and the just-introduced 2016 Chevrolet Spark minicar. Generally displayed on a car’s touchscreen, but sometimes in a section of the rearview mirror, the camera image shows you what’s behind your car when you’re in Reverse. That’s especially a boon to people with mobility issues and those driving tall crossovers or SUVs, but it can help any driver in any kind of vehicle do a better job of avoiding obstacles.

The 2015 Honda Fit and CR-V are two examples of popular vehicles with a multi-angle rearview camera as standard. You can choose a normal (direct rear) view, a top-down view that helps you with parking, or a wide-angle view that shows you what other vehicles are coming up from the side.
15,000 people are injured every year in backover accidents. Knowing those numbers are going to drop once everybody has a rearview camera? Priceless.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) says 210 people die, and 15,000 are injured, every year because of backover accidents...and 31 percent of those deaths are children. Knowing those numbers are going to drop once everybody has a rearview camera? Priceless.

2. Enjoy a 360-degree view.

Increasingly, automakers are fitting their higher-end vehicles with a set of cameras that let you see all the way around your vehicle. The 2016 Jaguar XF shown here is an example. It has five cameras positioned all around the car that show you the road ahead, plus a view of what’s around you from every angle. These cameras do more than give you a look; they interface with technology such as lane departure warning and blind spot monitoring systems that can give you a visual or sound warning and even override your driving with a correction. The 360-degree view is so useful that it’s likely to trickle down to become at least optional equipment on a wide variety of vehicles. For now, you can find it on cars like the 2015 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class and Kia K900. On the 2015 Nissan Rogue, the four-camera system is called the Around View Monitor; cameras are located in the front, rear, and side mirrors.

3. Stay in your lane.

The 2016 Acura RLX has a windshield-mounted camera that can identify lane markings down to whether they’re solid or dashed and will then keep you accurately in the lane, providing warnings and applying steering help if you need it. Honda’s Lane Watch feature has a camera on the passenger’s-side mirror that shows you the road on the right of your car when your right turn signal is activated. This helps you be better informed when making a turn in an intersection.
Don’t be paranoid about being monitored; be grateful the technology just might save you from yourself.

4. Stay awake.

Volvo's 2016 XC90 has Driver Alert Control (shown here), which uses the vehicle’s 360-degree camera to keep an eye on you as the driver. If it determines you’re getting sleepy—which it can tell by whether your steering becomes slightly erratic—it will show you a cup of coffee and a message suggesting you go take a break. Mercedes-Benz pioneered this system with its Attention Assist. Don’t be paranoid about being monitored; be grateful the technology just might save you from yourself.

image.altText: 5 Mercedes Active Night View Assist Plus Spotlight

pageElements.text:
5. See in the dark.

Mercedes-Benz and BMW both offer night vision. BMW’s Intelligent Vision and Mercedes’ Night View Assist Plus (shown here) use infrared cameras to spot people or animals that may be in your path, up to several hundred feet ahead of your vehicle. You get a head-up display or instrument panel alert, while the headlights focus on the pedestrian or deer and the brakes prime themselves to be put into quick use if necessary.

6. Get help hooking up the trailer.

The 2015 Ford F-150 has a Dynamic Hitch Assist feature that uses a rear-mounted camera to show you how to line up your truck with the camper or trailer. Nobody has to get out of the truck and stand back there, gesturing and waving to help you figure out when you’re lined up with the trailer. You’ll just have to find some other way to test the strength of your marriage!

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive wagon
Base price: $27,815 (including destination charge)

Engine: Turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual (standard); six-speed automatic (optional)
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/35 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated front seats
Option I can't live without: Titan black leatherette interior (no-cost option)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, keyless access with push-button start, panoramic power tilting and sliding sunroof, cooled glove box, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob
Notable options on this model: Driver Assistance package (includes forward collision warning, park assist, $895)
You might also be considering: 2015 Honda Crosstour ($28,410); 2015 Subaru Outback ($25,745); 2015 Toyota Prius V ($27,575) (all prices include destination charges)

Let’s start with a little full-disclosure moment. The Jennings family owns a 2013 VW Jetta SportWagen TDI. We love our Jetta very much, and so does Bob, our Chesapeake show dog, for whom we bought our German wagen-with-an-e, equipped with a thrifty diesel engine.

We had been hauling Bob to dog shows around the country in a Chevrolet Suburban, equally loved (as is our Mazdaspeed Miata), but with the average fuel economy (14 mpg) of a Cessna. Once we confirmed that the Jetta diesel was delivering around 43 mpg on average (and our monthly fuel bill had dropped from $1,000 to a much more reasonable number), the Suburban became semi-retired, reserved for towing trailers and for three-dog-cage kennel transport..

Meanwhile, we have become enamored of the brand spanking new 2015 Golf SportWagen. It replaces the Jetta SportWagen, so, while my Jetta wagon is still cool, it has suddenly become obsolete. It is no more.

But that’s okay, because the new SportWagen looks radically more modern and sleek and everything cool, suddenly making my black Jetta wagon that much more drab and dusty next to it. (Note to self: Do not let husband buy a black car ever again.) The sheetmetal is more shapely, the headlamps and taillamps more artful and technically superior.
This SportWagen is all Golf, and all Golfs are good. Even the ones that aren’t sports cars like the zingy GTI and the powerful R are are satisfying and special.

The Golf lineup was voted 2015 North American Car of the Year, and this SportWagen completes the new Golf portfolio. It is all Golf, and all Golfs are good. Even the ones that aren’t sports cars like the zingy GTI and the powerful R are satisfying and special in that Teutonic way. It is tightly screwed together, the seats are a comfortable chair height, and the focus is on the driver. The steering is precise, and the brakes are satisfyingly direct.
The new Golf SportWagen can be ordered with a 2.0-liter turbo-diesel engine making 150 horsepower (TDI) or a 1.8-liter four-cylinder turbocharged gasoline engine making 170 horsepower (TSI).
No matter which engine you choose, the Golf SportWagen is more nimble than any comparable compact crossover, a category that most wagon buyers are probably also considering.

But there’s the elephant in the room. Station wagon. Two words that don’t clinic well with America’s car shoppers. That confounds Europeans, who love their station wagons. Of course, they call them SportWagens (VW), Avants (Audi), estate cars, et cetera, instead of station wagons. And they buy them with turbo-diesel engines.

The Golf SportWagen I drove was the TSI, with the four-cylinder gasoline engine. A lot of American shoppers might prefer it over the excellent turbo-diesel engine in this VW.
It’s paired with a five-speed manual transmission or an optional six-speed automatic. The TDI, the diesel model, has a six-speed manual transmission as standard that’s perfectly geared for maximum performance, with an automatic optional. If you hesitate to consider the diesel, let me suggest that you reconsider that. You get better fuel economy with the turbo-diesel, and you also get more range—about 488 miles between fillups, compared with around 395 for the gasoline engine. Not having to stop and fill the tank on a long drive is a great benefit of a diesel.

The Golf wagon is 1.1 inches longer than the outgoing Jetta wagon, and its wheelbase has grown by 2.2 inches. Yet the wagon is almost an inch lower for what VW calls a more “muscular” look. It may be under $30,000, but it has its share of amenities. Standard on the TSI SE I tested were a panoramic sunroof with power tilt and slide, a cooled glove box, heated front seats, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, and Bluetooth connectivity. It also came with seventeen-inch alloy wheels, and our test car had a Driver Assistance package ($895) that includes forward collision warning and park assist technology.
The new Golf lineup has also been modernized inside. The look and feel are really quite striking, making the SportWagen feel like a much more expensive vehicle.

My husband is a no-frills kind of hunter-gatherer. He combed the country to find a stripped version of the 2013 Jetta SportWagen TDI and managed to find one that had only floor mats and a first aid kit as options. He added a protective metal strip on the rear to easily slide the dog crate in and out of the cargo hold. Surprisingly, he discovered that air conditioning, Bluetooth hands-free phone, and heated front seats were all standard equipment.

Wait until he hears that the standard Golf SportWagen TDI also adds keyless access with push-button start and a rearview camera. As exciting as that is to me, he will be more impressed to discover that the price of the 2015 SportWagen TDI will be almost $2,000 less than our 2013 Jetta version.

Where am I going with this? Yes. After two years, the family Jetta is being readied for the block, and plans are afoot to buy the lower, longer, wider, lighter, more fuel-efficient, more loaded Golf SportWagen TDI S.

Lincoln design director David Woodhouse has been working toward his current role of crafting Lincoln’s future for most of his fifteen years with the Ford Motor Company.  He jumped ship from General Motors U,K. in 1999 to become chief designer of Ford’s once prestigious Premier Automotive Group, which comprised Jaguar, Land Rover, Aston Martin, and Volvo.

When asked why Ford did not see fit to include Lincoln as part of the group, PAG’s imperious group president, Wolfgang Reitzle, sniffed, "Because then we would have to call it the Almost Premier Auto Group." He was not wrong.

After chief designer stints in Ford’s California advanced design studio and at its Ingeni strategic concepts group, Woodhouse  was ready for the monumental task of putting Lincoln back on the map.  With only a few months of  directing strategy under his 
belt, Woodhouse took over as Lincoln’s director of design at the end of 2013.

He showed us the 2016 MKX Concept at the 2014 North American International Auto Show a month after he assumed the role of director of design, but the Continental Concept is his first true breakout design for the beleaguered brand.

pageElements.text: Looking for a new vehicle for you and your dog(s)? Our dogs would like to have a word with you about that. They’re all old hands at riding and have served at various times as subjects of our dog safety gear tests. Here are a few things our hounds want you to keep in mind when you’re scouting the aisles at the dealership.

Bizee: I want to see what’s out there. Put yourself in my place—which should always be the back, damn it. Are the windows at least low enough that I can see the world going by? Are they tinted so it stays cooler back there, and there’s not too much glare? Come on, people!

Stella: I want to be able to get in the car without being touched. Listen. Now that I’m fourteen, I can’t leap up into a tall vehicle on my own, and I can’t really be lifted up without a lot of pain. I know I should be able to go up that ramp my humans bought for me, but it wouldn’t scare me now if they’d trained me when I was young. Reject! There are a lot of variations in how high a car or SUV rides up off the ground, so bring your dog with you for its own test ride. I’d suggest you look carefully at station wagons and minivans and, really, any kind of hatchback—I can jump in all of those.
At least they figured out how to back up to the deck so I could just stroll in.

One more thing: I want to be cool enough, or warm enough, or generally have some of the same comforts you have in the front seat. Heated rear seats feel so good on my old arthritic bones. Good ventilation in the back rows is less common than you’d think—please check for A/C vents and controls back where your best friend will be riding.

Ray the Stray: I like to have a spot that’s just for me. My crate is in the back seat. Bob and Stella are in the back, Stella on the left, Bob on the right. We’re all safe and sound. Check for split-folding rear seats, or a rear hatch area big enough for your dog’s crate. It’s the safest and most secure place. The excellent website Vetstreet gets that recommendation straight from a veterinarian. I know I like to ride in the front seat with my tongue hanging out the passenger’s-side window. It’s not where any dog should be.
Also, I get nervous when I see cars going by in the side window next to me. I wish we had a window shade to make sure the view outside doesn’t flip me out and make me carsick.
How easily can you vacuum the back seats? Seriously, did you really consider beige plush fabric? You need something easier to clean.

Bob: Sorry about the shedding. I know cars cost a lot of money, and although I want to get comfortable, I’m (sort of) willing to live by the family housekeeping rules. So do your part. Look at the interior and make sure it will still look okay a year from now, even if your dog is in the car with you every day. (My dream.) How easily can you vacuum the back seats? Seriously, did you really consider beige plush fabric? You need something easier to clean. This is why so many dog owners loved the late, lamented Honda Element, which could be practically hosed out in the back. Get rubber mats, blankets, whatever will work to approximate that cleanability. If you’re happy, I’m happy.

But I know you already know that. Thanks.

And don’t forget the treat holders.

pageElements.text: Cadillac’s exterior design manager, Taki Karras,  met me at the New York Auto Show to walk me around the 2016 CT6, on my short list of must-see cars.

First, Taki’s name is Greek. I don’t know what it means, but I do know how to pronounce it. Not like a Greek taco. Not like the Easter Island torches. It’s ‘Tikey” like “Mikey.” He looks too young to have been at General Motors for fifteen years, but he’s had quite an auspicious career there, after graduating from DAAP, the prestigious college of Design, Architecture, Art and Planning at the University of Cincinnati.

The GM years have included stints as lead exterior designer at Pontiac, the Small Midsize Studio, California Advanced Studio, and at Cadillac before being elevated to Cadillac’s exterior design manager.

He is uniquely qualified to guide us on a walking tour of the car first hinted at in a sultry ad during the Oscars. We’ve been wanting to see more ever since.
Here it is.

title: 2016 Fiat 500X
subTitle: The cute 500, sized for the mainstream small-crossover buyer.

promoTeaser: The cute 500, sized for the mainstream small-crossover buyer.
metaDescription: The cute 500, sized for the mainstream small-crossover buyer.

pageElements.text:
2016 Fiat 500X Lounge

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Base price: $25,750
Price as tested: $27,300
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower
Transmission: Nine-speed automatic
Fuel economy (estimated): 23 mpg city/32 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Nine-speed automatic transmission
Option I can’t live without: Rosso Amore paint ($1,000)
Notable standard features on this model: 17-inch aluminum alloy wheels, Uconnect infotainment system with 6.5-inch touchscreen, navigation, heated steering wheel, heated side mirrors, fog lamps, height-adjustable rear cargo floor
Notable options on this model: Black leather seats, park assist, blind spot monitor, rear cross-traffic detection (all included in Lounge Collection 2, $1,550)
You might also be considering: 2015 Buick Encore, ($24,990), 2015 Chevrolet Trax LTZ ($25,905), 2015 Kia Soul + ($19,515), 2015 Nissan Juke ($21,075)

It may seem unlikely at a glance, but there’s a strong parallel between culinary art and automotive design. Consider this new Fiat, a recipe composed of familiar ingredients, the same ones the company employed to cook up the Jeep Renegade. Same foundations, same powertrains, the fundamentals that define any motor vehicle.

But of course the 500X does not aspire to be a semi-serious sport-utility vehicle like the Renegade. Fiat characterizes it as a small crossover, a description that also applies to the Renegade, but it lacks hardware options that give its Jeep cousin real off-road credibility. Naturally, there’s not a trace of Renegade in the sheetmetal, which is reminiscent of the now-familiar subcompact 500,  albeit on a substantially larger scale: 27.6 inches longer overall, on a wheelbase (101.2 inches) that’s 10.6 inches longer. It’s also much wider, as well as 3.3 inches taller.
What’s interesting in all this is that the dimensions of the 500X are quite similar to those of the 500L, the four-door version of the tiny 500 that came along for the 2014 model year.
The 500X is quick on its feet, and its solid structure and firm suspension tuning provide a high order of handling response.
The 500X is more carlike than the L, which Fiat describes as “more utilitarian,” but the interior volumes are very close and the distinctions between the two seem subtle.
Nevertheless, the 500L will continue in the lineup for the foreseeable future, according to Fiat.

Like the Renegade, the 500X is basically a front-wheel-drive design, with the option of all-wheel drive, albeit a less sophisticated system than that employed in the Jeep. And it shares the Renegade’s powertrain offerings: a 160-horsepower 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder (standard) and a 2.4-liter 4-cylinder rated for 180 horsepower. The 1.4-liter turbo is available with a six-speed manual, and the 2.4-liter is paired with a nine-speed automatic.

Bigger on the outside means bigger on the inside, and in the 500X it means rear seats capable of accommodating adults, with just a little cooperation from those up front, something that can’t be said for the little 500. Asterisk: Fiat says “comfortable seating for five,” but that's a bit of a stretch.

The X retains the stylish dashboard of the 500, which is both distinctive and retro-cool, and of course there are good connectivity (Uconnect), audio (Beats), and navigation options. The front seats are more comfortable than those in the standard 500 (although there could be a bit more lateral support for hard cornering), there’s more elbow room, armrests and door panels are nicely padded, and Fiat has done a pretty good job of suppressing interior noise.

All but one of the cars in I tested in California this week were equipped with the 2.4-liter engine and nine-speed transmission, which is likely to be the volume-selling combination. It delivers respectable acceleration, and the nine-speed is nicely programmed to keep the engine in the sweet spot of its powerband.
A new Dynamic Selector system offers three operating modes—Auto, Sport, and Traction—and in a half-day of driving the distinctions came across as subtle.

Nevertheless, the X’s solid structure and firm suspension tuning provide a high order of handling response. The 500X is quick on its feet, with limited body roll and precise steering. It would be better if the nine-speed could be operated with paddle shifters, as well as the gear selector, a curious cost saving in a sporty hatchback. It’s also curious that Fiat decided to omit adaptive cruise control from the U.S. version of the 500X, even though it’s offered in other markets.
Fiat wasn’t ready to announce EPA fuel economy forecasts. An educated guess, based on the Renegade, suggests 23 mpg city, 32 highway.

The Verdict:

There are five trim levels, named in Fiat 500 style as Pop, Easy, Trekking, Lounge, and Trekking Plus. Wonderful for when people ask about your car: it’s a Fiat 500X Lounge, thank you. Base prices range from $20,900 to $28,000. Our test subject here—the Lounge version—had most of the X’s upscale goodies, including Uconnect infotainment, Beats audio, an optional array of standard safety features, plus rear park assist, rear cross-path detection, and blind spot monitoring. Total price was $27,300, although you can get the base 500X for $20,900. The online configurator is up to compare.

For the price of our test car, you could equip yourself with a Volkswagen Golf GTI—similar size, similar interior room, substantially more performance. Still, for buyers who enjoy agile dynamics and the Cinquecento’s distinctively Italian persona, the 500X will rank pretty high on the small-hatchback scale.

You might also be considering: Acura ILX, BMW 2 Series, Buick Verano, Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class

The A3 makes a comeback in an all-new sedan for 2015 designed to appeal to entry-luxury buyers. The compact four-door is also available in a performance-oriented S3 and a two-door convertible. Audi has added some playful retro touches to the clean, well-thought-out interior that is the hallmark of this automaker. The infotainment system (MMI) includes navigation; the A3 also comes with a long list of standard features including a panoramic sunroof, dual-zone climate control, and leather-trimmed seats. Lovers of advanced driving technology will appreciate Audi Drive Select that allows you to adjust the performance characteristics of the car, the Pre Sense Basic system that preps the vehicle’s restraint systems when an emergency maneuver is detected, and a 4G LTE data connection. Those who long for the sporty silhouette of the old A3 hatchback will have to wait for the upcoming 2016 A3 Sportback TDI or the Sportback e-tron hybrid model that promises 204 horsepower. For now, you can choose among seven variants, four body styles, and five unique engines in the A3/S3 family.

New for 2015

The A3 is an all-new model for 2015.

Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Three-zone climate control in all A4s
Notable standard features on this model: LED daytime running lights and taillights
Notable options on this model: S line competition package, available on Premium Plus and Prestige trims, gives the A4 sharp black accents inside and out as well as a distinctive leather/Alcantara interior
You might also be considering: BMW 3 Series, Cadillac ATS, Infiniti Q50

Not a lot has changed this year for Audi’s A4 sedan, and that’s a good thing. It is still luxurious inside, handsome on the outside, and a capable performer on the road. If you're looking for a bit more excitement, Audi offers the S4 version, with all-wheel drive, a supercharged V-6, and your choice of either a seven-speed automatic or a six-speed manual transmission. The base A4 comes very well equipped but techno- and audiophiles will want to opt for the MMI Navigation Plus package with voice control and the Bang & Olufsen sound system. Advanced safety options are also available including Audi’s Side Assist that monitors blind spots and can detect fast-approaching vehicles.

There’s quite a span of A4’s to be had between the Premium and the S4 Prestige trims along with three transmission choices. The handling poise and classic styling of the A4 and S4 stack up nicely against the competition. Interiors in both feel airier than those of the BMW 3-series or the Cadillac ATS although the rear seat is a bit cozier than in those models and the 12.4-cubic-foot trunk is on the small side. For the exterior check out the new metallic paint options like Florett Silver, Mythos Black, and Utopia Blue to liven up your driveway. The A4 is luxurious, while the S4 is the higher-performance choice.

New for 2015

Three-zone climate control and the S line style package are now standard on all A4s.

If choice is high on your list of luxury coupe criteria, the A5 will not disappoint. It comes in a variety of configurations from the base A5 coupe to the off the hook, 450-horsepower RS 5 convertible. The price range is just as wide, ranging from just under $41,000 to more than $80,000. Changes for this year are largely cosmetic including newly available 18-inch, 10-spoke wheels on the A5 and menacing 20-inch matte black wheels on the RS 5. The A5's 2.0-liter four-cylinder produces a respectable 220 horsepower and in coupe form can be equipped with either a manual or automatic transmission; convertibles are only available with an automatic. 2015 brings added color choices. The interior showcases Audi’s trademark luxury with refined inlays on the dash and doors as well as helpful LED lighting in the footwells.

Although its last full redesign was several years ago, the A6's decidedly German sheetmetal still looks fresh. Previous technical updates included a more rearward position for the engine. The infotainment system includes a touchpad, capable of receiving input through handwriting. A turbo-diesel rounds out the offerings.

You might also be considering: Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class, Porsche Panamera

With a svelte profile and a massive rear hatch, the A7 pairs the elegance of a coupe with superior functionality and space, while providing the performance one expects in a high-end German car. Quattro all-wheel drive is standard across the lineup with no fewer than four engines to choose from. The base A7 can be equipped with either a 310-horsepower, supercharged V-6 or a turbo-diesel V-6 that produces 428 pound-feet of torque and achieves a respectable 38 mpg on the highway. Then there's the S7’s V-8 engine, boasting 420 horses and capable of reaching 155 mph. The RS 7’s 4.0-liter V-8 pushes the envelope even further with 560 horsepower and the ability to reach 60 mph in 3.7 seconds. It relies on a specially tuned twin-turbo V-8 to reach a top speed of 174 mph.

The cabin is designed for efficient comfort with elegant inlays. The Prestige package adds perforated leather and four-zone climate controls. The sweeping roofline encroaches on headroom in an otherwise roomy interior. Driver assistance technology abounds, including an optional head-up display and Night Vision Assist to detect pedestrians and wildlife on dark roads. Audi’s trademark Google Earth map technology is also available, as is Bang & Olufsen stereo.

New for 2015

A head-up display and full LED headlights are now standard on A7 Prestige models.

subTitle: It's all about you. Seriously. Here's how to make sure it stays that way.
promoTitle: 7 Ways to Put Joy into Car Shopping
promoTeaserSmall: It's all about you. Seriously. Here's how to make sure it stays that way.
promoTeaser: It's all about you. Seriously. Here's how to make sure it stays that way.
keywords: 7 Ways to Put Joy into Car Shopping
metaTitle: 7 Ways to Put Joy into Car Shopping
metaDescription: It's all about you. Seriously. Here's how to make sure it stays that way.

pageElements.text: How does shopping for a new car fit into your life? Is it right up there at the desirability level of a trip to the spa, or way down low next to a root canal?

Let me tell you how I feel about new-car shopping: You should be thrilled. You’re about to buy a brand-new car! You should take your time to revel in every moment and make the whole experience be about you. The lucky dealer owes it to you to listen carefully to you, to give you answers that make sense, and to build your enthusiasm, not sidetrack it or knock it down.
To get there, you need to put yourself into the right mindset. Then you’ll be able to put all the elements in place that will make the experience work for you.

1. Believe that this is all about you.

It’s your money. It’s going to be your car. Too many people let car shopping feel like a dreaded chore. Don’t. Going on a tropical vacation, or buying a fabulous piece of jewelry, the hottest new putter, or a collector’s edition book….those things are fun. Buying a car should be all of that, multiplied by about 100. You are spending enough money to give you the absolute right to actually enjoy choosing and closing the deal on your car.

2. Know what you want before you walk in.

You can greatly reduce the stress of car buying by walking into the dealership already armed with information you need. Every brand you could possibly be interested in has an online presence these days. Go to the manufacturers’ websites and play with the excellent online car configurator tools. Specifically, try to understand what packages are available on the model you’re interested in, and what different trim levels your vehicle of choice can come equipped with. Print that information, and put it on a clipboard. Once you’ve narrowed down the different cars you like, comparison shop on dealer websites. The more you have explored and decided on your own needs and wants, the more you’ll be able to relax and enjoy the shopping experience.

3. Know how much you have to spend. Really.

It’s a good time to check your credit score and get pre-qualified by your bank or credit union. Find out about their loan rates and deals. In short, don’t show up at the dealership until you are clear on the financial aspects and have a clear idea about your spending limit. It makes no sense to be distracted by cars on the lot that are priced beyond your means. Knowing your financial status sends a message to your salesperson that you’re serious about buying.

One last thing: Don’t be surprised if the dealer can get you a better rate on your loan.

4. Expect respect from your salesperson.

Start the relationship on a high note. Make an appointment and start to establish a connection before you just wander in. You may also get an idea of your compatibility before you ever walk through the door. Assume that the salesperson is a professional and is there to help you find your dream car and facilitate your ownership. It’s not fair to start the process with a chip on your shoulder or an assumption that the salesperson is out to cheat you—not fair to the salesperson, but also not fair to yourself.

5. Make your first trip to the dealership a fact-finding mission.

This is a good time to get your bearings without the pressure of decision-making. This is also a great time for that first appointment, to decide if you click with the salesperson. Bring your clipboard and a list of any questions you might have. Tell them upfront that you won’t be testing, just shopping. Say it again if you have to

6. Don’t let anyone set the timetable for you.

Don’t be in a hurry at any stage of the process. When you’re ready for your test drive, bring along all the props and baggage of your daily life—dog crates, child seats, briefcases, or whatever else you know you’ll load into the car the minute you own it—and make sure it fits. Take all the time you need—all the time you want—to truly test drive the car. Let absolutely nobody pressure you into making a decision before you’re ready.

7. Be prepared to keep trying, or walk away, if the salesperson doesn’t give you the experience you want.

This is the most important element. You are not required to work with the first salesperson you encounter. You don’t have to buy any one car from any one dealership. There are lots of fish in the sea dying to jump on your hook. Your best weapons are being ready and willing to spend the amount of money you have decided you can spend, along with being ready and willing to walk away if the deal isn’t going to happen. You don’t need to be rude. You don’t have to get mad. You just need to be your own best advocate.

title: Real World Test: Adaptive Cruise Control
subTitle: Is this the next best thing to a self-driving car? We tried it on the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country.
promoTitle: Real World Test: Adaptive Cruise Control
promoTeaserSmall: Is this the next best thing to a self-driving car? We tried it on the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country.
promoTeaser: Is this the next best thing to a self-driving car? We tried it on the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country.
keywords: Real World Test: Adaptive Cruise Control
metaTitle: Real World Test: Adaptive Cruise Control - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Is this the next best thing to a self-driving car? We tried it on the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: There can be meditative beauty in driving, but that's not something that happens for everyone every day. The open road (or more likely, bumper-to-bumper traffic) is too often just a reminder that there is a laundry list of other things we could be doing. For those days, autonomous cars are soon going to do the dirty work for us. But until that day arrives, there's technology like adaptive cruise control, a feature of the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country. (It's part of a $1,500 Technology package option, although it's standard on the uplevel Platinum model.)

Although its name is similar to the cruise control you’ve been taking for granted for decades, Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC) is truly a stepping stone to those futuristic self-driving cars making their way down the product pipeline.
If the vehicle in front of you slows or one merges in front of you, the ACC will reduce throttle or apply the brake until the preset time interval is reached.

Cruise control simply maintains the vehicle at a set speed. However, the “adaptive” part adds the ability to slow down and speed up your car to keep pace with the flow of traffic, and even bring it to a complete stop if needed. The only thing it won’t do for you is steer.

ACC works using one or more radar sensors paired with a camera in the front of the car. The driver sets his or her top speed, and then configures the trailing distance behind the car in front of him. ACC calculates that trailing distance by miliseconds, and will adjust the vehicle’s speed to maintain that time interval.

If the vehicle in front of the car slows or if a vehicle merges in front of the car, the ACC will reduce throttle or apply the brake until the preset time interval is reached and keep pace with the vehicle it’s trailing. If there are no vehicles in front of the car, the car will accelerate to the maximum set speed.
So what’s it like sharing the driving responsibility with a car? To find out I tested this feature in the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country for a week.

Volvo is kind enough to make its owner's manual searchable and viewable on the LCD screen, for a complete explanation. However, the operation of adaptive cruise control was rather intuitive even without consulting it. Unlike some vehicles, the ACC controls on the V60 Cross Country were accessible directly on the steering wheel rather than on a stalk behind it, which made it easier to reach, use, and modify. Within minutes and a few tries, I was more or less letting the car do the driving for me.

As I began to trust the car to do what it’s supposed to do, including stop if needed, I could feel the lure of more freedom to do other things, like fiddle with the radio, adjust the temperature, and play with other vehicle features. I had such confidence in the technology that I was tempted to take a photo of the instrument panel for this article, but was duly reminded that it was illegal by an electronic sign alerting me of a distracted driving campaign in effect.

But text messages and smartphones aren’t the way to get distracted to the point of narrowly avoiding a collision. I can’t be the only one who has made a cursory glace at the radio to change a station or look at a map only to have to slam on the brakes when I looked back up and realized that traffic had come to a halt in that split second I didn’t have my eyes glued to the brake lights in front of me.
And this is precisely the type of scenario that ACC is designed for, which is made even better with Volvo’s addition of Queue Assist.

In heavy stop-and-go traffic, Queue Assist will bring the vehicle to a complete stop and start again when the target vehicle in front advances. Without Queue Assist, the ACC would disengage if the vehicle came to a complete stop, and the driver would have to manually resume ACC. However, this feature will remain activated even if the vehicle comes to a complete stop, but requires the driver to tap on the gas pedal to reactivate the system if stopped for more than five seconds.
You need to be aware of surroundings and check if the system is still in effect. Not much of a tradeoff to avoid ever having to slam on your brakes suddenly.

The system isn’t perfect. ACC uses radars and cameras to keep track of the vehicles in front of it, and could lose track of the target it’s following on curvy or hilly roads. This means that the driver isn’t entirely off the hook. You need to remain aware of your surroundings and check if the system is still in effect, which isn’t a much of a tradeoff to avoid being surprised by unexpected braking.

Even if it’s still shy of a self-driving car, it has the potential to reduce traffic congestion and avoid collisions, which will save money, time, and lives. Luckly it’s becoming available in more vehicles, and making it worthy option to invest in if it’s available in a car that you’re buying. Unless, of course, you find meditative beauty in stop-and-go traffic.

In 2014, Audi simplified its venerable sports car taking the TT and TTS down one trim by dropping the TT RS from the lineup. Distinctly designed from the beginning to show off its Audi heritage in an attractively bold package, the TT still offers a fine German sports car, nicely priced between $41,000 and $53,000. For 2015, Audi is offering a fixed rear spoiler as part of the TTS Competition package, as well as two new exterior color choices: Nimbus Grey and Imola Yellow. The TT’s interior melds racing-car design cues with high-end features like optional baseball stitched sport seats and an optional navigation system that has two SD slots for your portable media. You can achieve more than 30 miles to the gallon on the highway, which you won’t find every day in a car as quick as the TT.

The TT has Quattro all-wheel drive and an automatic rear spoiler that raises or lowers as speed dictates. Style choices for the TT increase in 2015 with a new S Line plus Carbon package that dresses up the base model with carbon fiber, aluminum, and black accents inside and out. Boost the looks of the TTS with the Black Optic package for high gloss accents and nineteen-inch wheels. Or you may want to opt for the perfectly proportioned convertible that sports a quick-folding acoustic roof.

New for 2015

A new five-arm wheel design is now standard on all TT models.
A fixed rear spoiler is part of the TTS Competition package.
New S line plus Carbon package features carbon, aluminum, and black accents on base TT.

The A8, Audi’s top-of-the line sedan, grew a little more muscle in 2015. A more sculpted hood, wider tailpipes, reshaped LED headlights, and a beefed-up grille add personality on the outside while the 4.0-liter engine received an additional 15 horsepower for a total of 435 horsepower. For 2015, buyers will be able to choose between regular- and long-wheelbase models for both 3.0-liter and 4.0-liter A8s. The entire A8 line, which also includes the sporty S8 and the flagship W12, comes standard with Quattro all-wheel drive. High-quality, luxurious cabins also come standard with a wide variety of leather options, as well as aluminum and wood dash and door inlays. As one would expect, the A8 comes chock-full of technology including Audi’s MMI system with a touchpad designed to read handwritten instructions. Enjoy a bevy of driver assist options from a 360-degree view camera to automatic high/low beams that adjust to oncoming traffic, to blind spot detection, and much more.

Although it’s one of the larger vehicles in this pricey segment, the A8 achieves good highway fuel economy with the V-6 and the TDI returning 29 mpg and 36 mpg, respectively. The S8's 520-horsepower twin-turbo V-8 gets from 0 to 60 mph in 3.9 seconds. From the base 333-horsepower supercharged V-6 to the 500 horsepower W-12, the A8 is really about superior engineering and impressive speed as much as that classy interior.

New for 2015

The A8 and S8 get redesigned front and rear fascias.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/TbYwmhRbX5A" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Like so many talented women in automotive design around the world, Helen Emsley has lived for years in the relative obscurity of the color and trim studio. Eleven of her twenty-plus years were spent at GM’s Opel division before being sent to the U.S. as GM’s first-ever global director of color and trim, elevating both her status and the importance to GM of cohesive interior design among all its brands.

Real fame came when GM design boss Ed Welburn anointed Emsley (to her shock) to lead the interior design of the Corvette. The result was simply the most beautiful, rational, and comfortable Corvette cabin in recent history. Emsley was also made design director of full-size truck interiors, and she likes to point out that the Corvette was GM’s most iconic brand, and the large trucks its most lucrative. “I told Ed he’d better sell his stock,” she laughs.

Instead, Welburn made her global director of GMC design and user experience in 2013. Emsley approached our first meeting (and my attendant videographer) with a down-to-earth manner and self-deprecating humor that is apparent during our walkaround of the updated GMC Terrain mid-size crossover. Although the changes are modest for 2016, Emsley’s presence has made GMC a brand worth watching.
