The Audi R8 is the exception to the rule that all Audis are elegant and sedate. Elegant, yes, but the R8's ground-hugging stance and sculpted side panels is on another, more sporting level entirely. Equipped with the automatic transmission, the 4.2-liter engine propels the R8 coupe from 0 to 60 in 4.2 seconds. The R8 V10 makes the same sprint in 3.4 seconds. Audi has gone to significant lengths to create a sports car that is as comfortable around town as a sedan. All R8s have Audi’s Quattro all-wheel-drive system. A cozy high-tech interior accommodates two tall adults comfortably in leather-stitched sport seats. Drivers can choose between a handsome coupe and a convertible, although the R8 V10 Plus is available as a coupe only. A lighter, flatter, more powerful 2016 model R8 made its debut at the Geneva Auto Show in March, so that's something to look forward to next year.

After a seven-year hiatus, Audi reintroduced the Allroad in 2013 to compete in the popular and growing crossover market. Suiting adventurous scenarios and American tastes, the Allroad sits higher off the ground than its European cousin the A4 Avant. As always, Audi works to marry style with performance. The sole powertrain, a turbocharged four-cylinder mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission, is smooth and powerful. Xenon headlights and leather seating are both standard. Audi’s Connect technology can turn the car into a roving Wi-Fi hot spot. Side Assist blind spot monitoring technology and adaptive cruise control are available options. Cargo space is respectable—27.6 cubic feet with the rear seats up, 50.5 cubic feet with the rear seats folded—but the Q5 offers more room for less money. The Allroad remains an appealing option for those seeking all-wheel capability in a refined family wagon.

Holy Hellzapoppin! Get a good look at this Creamsicle orange, bespoilered beast called the Lexus RC350, and know for real that the somnambulant boulevard cruising days of Lexus are over.
The wild origami-folded coupe, with its Darth Vader creases front and rear, is as far as you can imagine from the first Lexus.

The wild origami-folded coupe, with its Darth Vader creases front and rear, is as far as you can imagine from the first Lexus, a pseudo-Mercedes-Benz LS400 sedan that came to the United States in 1989.
That color is actually Molten Pearl, a name chosen last year in a contest on the Lexus Facebook page.

If you wonder what happened to the whisper-quiet, bland luxury for which Lexus was known, look no further than Akio Toyoda. He’s the grandson of Kiichiro Toyoda, founder of the company, Toyota, that took America by storm in the bad old fuel crisis days with basic, dead-reliable appliances.

I heard Akio’s story and dilemma from his own mouth: He was called out by Toyota chief test driver Hiromu Naruse for not being informed enough to offer valid comments about the company’s cars. So Toyoda assigned himself the job of learning high-performance driving from Naruse himself. He became so competent that he actually raced on factory teams and tested the LFA supercar at Germany’s notoriously difficult Nurburgring track.

Toyoda became good enough to also become disappointed in the appearance and performance of the Lexus lineup. “I realized that Lexus cars were not special because we did not make them special. They were engineered, designed, and built by Toyota employees to the standard of Toyotas. How could customers see them as competitors to Mercedes-Benz or BMW?”

The culmination of his changes to the position of Lexus within the company’s structure resulted in the creation of Lexus International, the only stand-alone unit within the vast Toyota organization. It also satisfied Akio Toyoda’s desire for strong design, as well as his passion for cars with sophisticated, high-performance handling characteristics.

The RC350 looks like more of a wild child than it is. Its 3.5-liter V-6 engine produces 308 horsepower, nice but by no means prodigious. (If you want a beast, go for the RC F, which starts above $60,000 and comes with a 467-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8.)

We all make assumptions when we look at a car. Looking at this one, you might assume it’s going to ride like a buckboard just because it looks like it’s about to rear back on its hind wheels and tear off down the street.

The RC350 is a Lexus at the core, which means it’s ultra refined. A lot 
of this has to do with the engineering that has gone into the structure.

Amazingly, based on its looks, the quality of the ride is exceptional. Small buzz bombs like the Subaru WRX STI are fiery and exhilarating to drive, but that exhilaration tends to wear off after you’ve driven about 100 miles. The RC350 is a Lexus at the core, which means it’s ultra refined. A lot 
of this has to do with the engineering that has gone into the structure.

I’ve admired Lexus interiors of late. I like the horizontal layouts of the dash and the instruments, and the RC350 is a sporty, very high-level, luxurious version of that dash. A lot of the money you spend on this car comes together in a beautifully executed interior. The most expensive option is the F Sport package ($3,895), which accounts for most of the extra oomph and presence of the car we tested. The package includes heated and ventilated sport seats, aluminum pedals, a perforated leather steering wheel and shift knob, and an adaptive variable suspension with a Sport S+ mode. When you turn the key, you go from a black instrument panel to a beautiful liquid crystal display that is as beautiful as any digital instrument cluster I’ve seen. When you tack on $2,610 for navigation, 17-speaker audio, and a rearview camera, and $1,000 for dynamic cruise control with pre-collision and intuitive park assist, you’ve brought that price all the way to $54,720. But you get a lot for that extra money. Do it.

Michigan has the perfect weather-ravaged roads to judge ride quality, and the first mile away from our office is our go-to crappy road-test surface. I got into the RC350 coupe after a long day at the office, and I prepared myself for a wild ride that never happened. It was perfectly composed, surprisingly so for a performance car with much more sporting pretension than you may associate with the luxury-oriented, super-silent, magic carpet Lexus brand.

It’s very difficult to have excellent handling and an exceptional ride. The former requires a fairly stiff chassis, and the latter demands a chassis that’s more compliant. Modern technology allows a much better blend of comfortable ride and precise handling, and this car has an amazing level of both.

When you step on the pedal and really give it some gas, you get a sound that’s not quite a roar, but the noise and the instant surge of power are satisfying, if not quite mind-boggling. You could be cruising very calmly along the freeway above the speed limit, then step on the gas, and you realize the RC350 actually is a bit of a beast. But it’s not a wild and crazy beast.

The Verdict:

The RC350 coupe is not a car for everyone. First of all, you can’t need the back seat for anything other than a couple of grocery bags. This is definitely an everyday car in terms of livability but not in terms of a wide range of uses. We’re not talking about a mini-ute here. We’re not talking about a four-door sedan, and the RC350 isn’t a muscle car. It’s a luxury sports car in the Japanese fashion. If you appreciate Akio Toyoda’s vision—of cars that make your right brain say, “I want this car,” of cars that are exciting to behold and satisfying to drive, the RC350 is a fine choice.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Not too many people in my professional life go back as far with me as John Cafaro, the executive director of Chevrolet Design. We are a year apart and met over the design of the 1984 Corvette C4. He’d been hired at General Motors in 1977, right out of Pratt Institute that same year, one day after his interview. One day later, he’d flown to Detroit and was immediately working under the great Corvette and Camaro design chief Jerry Palmer.

I met him while interviewing Palmer about the upcoming 1984 Corvette, who showed me a scrap of paper, one of many that together formed the radical new Corvette C4. That scrap had a pencil sketch of a clamshell hood. Cafaro had drawn it, Palmer went crazy for it, the C4 wore it into production, and it launched Cafaro on a career trajectory that included Camaro Z28, hot Bonnevilles, hot Fieros, the Corvette C5, and 2002 induction in the Corvette Hall of Fame.
Cafaro was the youngest chief of the famed Chevy 3 studio. He worked at Cadillac, on trucks, and he eventually made his way to executive director of Chevy car design.
Cafaro is the perfect guy to show us around the 2016 Malibu. For full details on the all-new mid-size car, here's our report.

As the roomiest Audi SUV, the Q7 is aimed at the luxury buyer who intends to bring along six passengers and tow the occasional boat as well. Fine engineering, luscious interiors, and performance are all present in the largely unchanged 2015 Q7. The few new options for 2015 include two exterior styling packages that use the Black optic theme also seen in other Audi products. Available on Premium Plus the Offroad Style Plus package offers Titanium wheels, black roof rails, fender flares, and bumpers. The Sport Style Plus package for Prestige models features oval exhaust outlets and gloss black wheels among its unique finishing touches. High-end bargain hunters will appreciate that the Q7’s base price starts below competitors like the BMW X5.

The front seats are abundantly roomy with a generous center storage compartment between driver and passenger. An available three-panel panoramic sunroof opens up the cabin beautifully and comes standard in the performance-minded S Line. The detailed and refined Q7 interior is the perfect habitat for infotainment features like navigation and parking, lane keeping, and trailer assist features.

New for 2015

Two new exterior styling packages are available for 2015: Offroad Style Plus and Sport Style Plus.

The Ford C-Max, introduced in 2013, comes in two environmentally friendly hybrid versions, the C-Max Energi plug-in hybrid and the C-Max Hybrid, the latter available in SE and SEL trims. The first thing you notice is how generous the inside of this small car feels thanks to a large windshield that goes into a tall roofline surrounded by large upright side windows. Legroom, front and rear, is also quite good.

The C-Max Hybrid, although a hatchback, is a small vehicle, with 24.5 cubic feet of cargo space in the Hybrid and only 19.2 cubic feet in the Energi, due to its larger battery pack. Underfloor bins provide additional cargo space in the second row. When you factor in standard voice-activated Sync infotainment system and the upscale feel to the interior, especially in the leather-clad SEL and Energi models, you have more than just an economical ride. The C-Max feels confident on the road with steering, power, and braking that respond well to inputs. Both models have a regenerative braking system that harnesses 95 percent of braking energy to charge the lithium-ion batteries. On the Energi, there is an EV Now mode that disconnects the gasoline engine to make the battery the sole source of power, with up to nineteen miles of range on electric power only.

New for 2015

The C-Max is unchanged from the previous year.

The Edge, which was originally introduced for the 2007 model year, has received a top-to-bottom overhaul for 2015. A redesigned suspension front and rear and improved structural rigidity—up 26 percent—give the Edge better ride and handling characteristics and reduce noise, vibration, and harshness. There are four Edge models and three engine choices, all of them served by Ford’s SelectShift automatic with steering-wheel-mounted paddles for manual control of the six-speed transmission. Increases in height, wheelbase, and overall length as well as interior improvements such as thinner seats have increased passenger and cargo volumes by 5.5 and 7.0 cubic feet, respectively.

The interior was totally redesigned as well with higher-quality materials and more storage options. The Sync infotainment system with MyFord Touch display is found on SEL trim and above. There are three engine options: an improved version of the 2.0-liter EcoBoost and two new V-6s, a 2.7-liter EcoBoost and a 3.5-liter. A new Titanium level Edge comes equipped with a comprehensive list of safety features including blind spot warning, lane departure warning, and inflatable second-row seatbelts. Lastly, Ford has made the Edge available with its auto stop/start system that saves fuel and reduces emissions by turning the engine off at stoplights.

A couple of years ago, the Escape emerged from a redesign so radical that it resembled its predecessor in name only. The new sporty Escape distinguished itself quickly in the very crowded small sport-ute segment with a unique look and a variety of upscale features. When you slide into the driver’s seat, the small-truck heritage of the Escape is nowhere to be found. The cabin is attractive and comfortable, and the controls are easy to reach and decipher. The Escape can be had in three trims: S, SE, and Titanium. The base S trim can only be equipped with the 168-horsepower 2.5-liter four-cylinder and front-wheel drive. The SE can be had with any of the three available engines, with front- or four-wheel drive, and with an options package that includes features such as a dual-zone automatic climate control and a backup warning system.

At the top of the Escape heap is the Titanium trim. It’s loaded up with premium touches, comes in front- or all-wheel-drive, and offers a choice between two turbocharged EcoBoost engines. That power will come in handy if you opt for the tow package that enables the Escape to pull up to 3,500 pounds. The hatch can swallow a respectable 34 cubic feet of stuff; that number doubles with the rear seats folded. Optionally, the adjustable, hands-free liftgate—it opens with a kick of your foot under the rear bumper—makes loading cargo a cinch. Like many Ford models, the Escape can be optioned with park assist, a system that takes control of the steering to help you parallel park, drama free.

The Expedition received a make-over for 2015 that includes a bolder front end, a more powerful twin-turbo engine, and a new Platinum trim, which should help it be a stronger competitor in the full-size sport-utility category. Both standard and extended-length Expedition EL models can accommodate eight, and the EL boasts 42.6 cubic feet of cargo space even with the seats fully occupied. The third row folds flat; a power-operated third row is optional on the XLT, standard on the remaining trims. The second row slides forward for easier access. Four trims are available, and each available with rear- or four-wheel drive. The entry-level XLT is equipped with standards like a leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel, a 4.2-inch display with USB connectivity, and a radar-based backup warning system. Limited buyers will enjoy the perforated leather seats and a power liftgate. The King Ranch version of the Expedition has a Southwest color palate for the perforated leather-trimmed seats—the front are heated and ventilated, while those in the second row are heated—and gets such niceties as remote start, power-deployable running boards, and an eight-inch touchscreen infotainment display. When optioned with the heavy-duty trailer package, the Expedition can tow up to 9,200 pounds, depending on the drivetrain. Select from three driving modes (Comfort, Normal, and Sport) that alter the suspension for a customized ride, and enjoy all that the new Expedition has to offer.

The 3.5-liter turbocharged V-6, a refreshed front end, more available features, and the Platinum trim level.

Ford’s venerable Explorer can be dressed down or gussied up, depending on your taste and budget. There are three available engines, and all but the four-cylinder can be had with all-wheel drive. The 2.0-liter turbo boasts a best-in-class highway fuel economy of 28 mpg, an impressive figure for a seven-seat sport-utility. Versatile seating options include the available PowerFold feature that lowers the third-row seats, second-row buckets with a useful center console, and leather and suede seat trim in the XLT appearance package. The Sport version of the Explorer gets a stiffer suspension, sport-tuned steering, larger brakes, steering-wheel-mounted paddle shifters, and the 365-horsepower, 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6. The ubiquitous F-150 underwent a radical transformation for 2015 that challenges the traditional notions of truck manufacturing. The body and bed are constructed of aluminum, making new F-150 models up to 700 pounds lighter than their predecessors. The frame is the same high-strength steel, but the new lighter sheetmetal is intended to better resist dents as well as help improve fuel economy, acceleration, hauling capacity, and stopping distances. With three cab choices, three bed lengths, four available engines, as well as five trim levels with increasing interior elegance and tech features, the line’s configurability is seemingly limitless and can take the F-150 from bare-bones work truck to powerful luxury hauler. Utility essentials like tow/haul mode, a cargo lamp, and roll stability and trailer sway control are standard on all F-150 models. The optional BoxLink system adds metal brackets and cleats allowing a variety of accessories—ramps, storage bins, bed dividers—to be secured in the cargo bed. Although the F-150’s styling is not as revolutionary as the much-touted aluminum construction, its stout front end, wide stance, and orderly interior suit its purpose nicely.

Aluminum alloy materials lighten the F-150 considerably.

The Optima is Kia’s mid-size mainstream sedan, a car that hit a styling bull's-eye in its current iteration, and thus the kind of make-over project that designers approach with a certain level of trepidation. Even a designer like Peter Schreyer, who happens to be Kia’s president, as well as capo di tutti capi of its styling studios.
The mandate: make it look new, but don’t get carried away.
The result is a sedan that Optima owners will instantly perceive as new, but others may need a bit of time and perhaps a quick tutorial. Which follows.
The snout of the new Kia has been stretched and reproportioned to yield a slightly more conventional look that’s still distinctive.

A quick clue to change in any car is usually visible in its nose. Current Kia vehicles share a commonality in this respect, a grille design that Schreyer characterized as a “tiger nose” when he created it a few years back. While the design is no more reminiscent of a tiger than it is of a crocodile, the version affixed to the snout of the new Kia has been stretched and reproportioned to yield a slightly more conventional look that’s still distinctive.

But if the changes to the sheetmetal are subtle, the engineers have been busy under the car. The wheelbase has been stretched almost half an inch, to 110.4 inches, and the bodyshell and chassis have been widened an inch, to 73.2 inches, expansions that pay dividends in terms of interior volume, as well as a more athletic stance—dare we say crouching tiger?

Kia also cites improvements in chassis rigidity—more high-strength steel, more industrial adhesives, more hot-stamped components—without furnishing specifics, and extensive noise-reduction measures, noteworthy in a car that was already quite serene on most roads.

There will be three engine offerings. The standard 2.4-liter four-cylinder (185 horsepower) and optional 2.0-liter turbo (247 horsepower) carry over from the current Optima. Both deliver power to the front wheels via a six-speed automatic transmission. A 178-hp 1.6-liter turbo and seven-speed dual-clutch automatic are new to the Optima family, limited to the LX trim level. Kia wasn’t ready to announce EPA ratings for this combo, but like the other engines it’s shared with the Hyundai Sonata, where it’s rated for 28 mpg city, 38 highway.

Consistent with most auto show introductions, Kia wasn’t ready to discuss pricing, either. Ranging across five trim levels—LX, LX Turbo, EX, SX Turbo, SXL—current Optima base prices go from about $22,500 to a little over $36,325.
The new Optima will reach Kia showrooms this fall.

That term—Four Door Sports Car—was central to marketing messages during the early years of Nissan’s premier sedan, a theme (and car) the company managed to dilute in a couple of recent generations, which were very hard to perceive as sporty.
It shouldn’t be a problem with this next generation, though. Longer, lower, wider, and attractively sculpted, the latest Maxima looks like it means business.

Specifications for the new chassis would seem to bear this out. According to Nissan, increased use of high-strength steel gives the new Maxima a 25 percent improvement in torsional rigidity, the critical starting point for agile handling, simultaneously paring 82 pounds from its curb weight.

Basic specs of the Maxima’s 3.5-liter V-6 engine are familiar, but Nissan insists that 62 percent of its parts are new, in an ongoing quest for more efficiency, blending performance (300 horsepower) with respectable EPA fuel economy ratings: 22 mpg city, 30 highway. The V-6 is paired with one of Nissan’s continuously variable automatics—the politically correct term within the corporation is Xtronic—programmed to allow step shifts, which can be initiated via shift paddles.

Another performance innovation is the Maxima’s new Drive Mode Selector, offering Sport and Normal presets. Each mode affects throttle response, transmission shifting, steering feel, and exhaust note, which Nissan calls Active Sound Enhancement. Draw your own conclusions about that.

As you’d expect, interior appointments have been upgraded across all five trim levels (S, SV, SL, SR, and Platinum). As you’d also expect, each trim level includes its own MSRP. What you might not expect is that each one represents an as-is model—there are no stand alone options or option packages.
How important is the Maxima to Nissan’s U.S. sales performance? Important enough that no less a personage than CEO Carlo Ghosn was on hand to pitch the new Maxima at its New York show debut.
The revivalist four-door sports car will be on sale this summer, with a base price of $33,235.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

The Fiesta’s appeal for first time buyers or the budget-conscious is undeniable. The price starts just under $15,000. The subcompact, in either hatchback or sedan form, sips fuel. Both versions are front-wheel drive with a choice between two small but willing engines: a 1.0-liter turbocharged three-cylinder and a 1.6-liter four-cylinder. Despite its humble starting price, the Fiesta comes standard with Ford’s voice-controlled Sync and can be optioned with the MyFord Touch infotainment system that includes navigation and AppLink. Another option is Ford MyKey, which shuts off audio until the seatbelts are fastened. Safety systems cannot be disabled, and parents are able to set volume and speed limits.

Two transmission choices, a five-speed manual or a six-speed automatic, are available on all three trims: S, SE and Titanium. The ST model enters hot-hatch territory with a six-speed manual transmission, sport suspension, and optional body-hugging Recaro racing seats in Molten Orange. The cabin is cozy, and very tall drivers may feel the roof is a bit too close for comfort, but the Fiesta’s interior is comfortable, attractive, and logically laid out. The joyful little Fiesta has a lot to offer for those looking for a fun ride in the compact segment.

Ford calls it a utility vehicle but the enigmatic Ford Flex has wagon written all over it. The long, low rectangle shape with a hint of old 1960s woody styling looks like nothing else on the road. With seating for seven and a decent 20 cubic feet of storage, to say this is a family-centric vehicle is an understatement. An optional second-row cooler compartment, back seat climate control, and electronic ports to create a Wi-Fi hot spot for passengers are all geared toward the tech-hungry and their kids. Parents will appreciate the fold-flat second- and third-row seats (powered third-row seats are optional) that extend the cargo capacity to 83 cubic feet. Large windows give the Flex’s cabin an airy feel, and the optional three-panel Vista Roof open’s it up even more. A plethora of video, navigation, and connectivity options are available if you add the Sync infotainment with MyFord Touch system that can be accessed by voice, steering wheel controls, or a tap on the eight-inch touchscreen. A backup sensor system that alerts you to obstructions behind the car is standard, but other safety options like inflatable seatbelts or blind spot warning are on higher trim levels only. All Flex models have a six-speed automatic transmission mated to either a normally aspirated or twin-turbocharged V-6 engine. The Flex Limited comes with the latter and all-wheel drive.

The Focus is a fun, affordable small car that is even more appealing for 2015. It offers nimble handling, great gas mileage, and, in the hatchback version, cargo utility, all in a modern, eye-catching package. The exterior received a refresh that gives it the critically acclaimed Fusion-style narrow grille and thinner head- and taillamps. LEDs are optional for both. The cabin gets new seat trim options, switches, and a revised center console and glove box. A heated steering wheel is newly available as well as a full suite of safety and connectivity technology including a rearview camera (standard for 2015), blind spot and lane keeping systems, and the Sync infotainment system with AppLink. The Focus also received a new stability control system and revised suspensions, front and rear, and the small but spunky 1.0-liter three-cylinder from the Fiesta is now available.

The ST model is the performance-oriented Focus. It comes only with a six-speed manual transmission to go with a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine, and it's fitted inside and out with sporty color schemes. Besides the Focus ST, there are four additional sedan or hatch models to suit every taste: the essentials only S, the mid-level SE, the loaded Titanium, and the plug-in Focus Electric hatch. The latter can reach 84 miles per hour and has an estimated range of 76 miles. Inside, an earth-friendly bio-foam fills the cushions, and the seat fabric is made entirely from recycled materials. But those who put a priority on green technology, can feel good about choosing any of the Focus models since even the gas versions of Focus are built in part with solar power at Ford’s Wayne, Michigan, plant. In either body style or any trim, the Focus offers a roomy interior in a small, parking friendly and fuel-efficient package.

With its debut as a 2008 model, the Enclave changed all perceptions of what a Buick could be. It brought a raked windshield, tapering roofline, and undulant bodywork to Buick showrooms, where the staff and clientele were accustomed to boxes. And it was introduced in brown, a rather daring color choice for the time. Since then, brown Enclaves have dotted American neighborhoods. How much has the Enclave changed? The 3.6-liter V-6 makes 13 more horsepower that it originally did and slightly better fuel economy in front-wheel-drive configuration. And there has been a progression of additional features, including this year’s heated wood steering wheel. But otherwise, it’s the same convenient, well-crafted big crossover as always: quiet and capable. To most eyes, it’s also beautiful. An all-new Enclave is expected for 2017, and it will have the advanced collision avoidance and other driver-assistance features lacking on the current model. In the meantime, there’s a strong value proposition for this Enclave. And you can always claim to be driving a future classic.

When the Buick Encore was introduced in 2013, the first question we asked was: Why? Who needs a short (168.4-inch) little crossover riding on 18-inch wheels? You sit up high, surveying the road as any visionary would, and although the turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder engine is small, it has enough push to keep you on the edge of the traffic wave. Body motions are well controlled, so there’s no bobbing when weaving. The Encore excels at commuting, and for Snow Belt duty, the available all-wheel drive is an excellent choice. Meanwhile, you can choose to get heated seats in the Encore's quiet cabin where Buick’s recent expositions of good taste come to the fore, especially in the mix of dark and light tones that can be chosen instead of the all-ebony interior. And like all others from the brand, the Encore is now equipped with 4G LTE with a Wi-Fi hot spot. As we’ve grown more accustomed to the Encore after the initial shock, we’ve come to understand the answer to our question of why. The Encore is fun, versatile, easy to maneuver, and cute.

The key statistic with the 2015 Buick LaCrosse is 101 cubic feet of passenger volume. The sedan does not come with overhead straps and rails for those who must stand in the aisle, but otherwise it’s like a bus. This is the big roomy American car for people who’d rather not get out their climbing gear and scale the sheer wall of an SUV. And as always, being a Buick, the LaCrosse represents a sensible value equation, even when it’s loaded with luxury, convenience, and safety features. Otherwise, it doesn’t much resemble the Buicks of yore. It comes with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine that’s aided by the “mild hybrid” eAssist feature, an electric drive system that delivers an extra shove in support of the combustion engine. The optional engine is the nice 3.6-liter V-6, and it can be paired with all-wheel drive for a sure-footedness that the good country doctor didn’t enjoy more than 100 years ago when making house calls in his Buick Model 10. The LaCrosse is everything Buick has always stood for: substantial, discreetly well appointed, durable, and a good value. One is eAssist, which uses an electric motor and current from a small lithium-ion battery to boost the 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine—a so-called mild hybrid system, yielding 36 mpg on the highway. On the other hand, you can go for the strong push in the back that everybody likes when dashing onto the freeway or around a slower vehicle. So the turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder generates 259 horsepower and a formidable 295 pound-feet of torque. To get that one, order the Regal GS with all-wheel drive. A record winter really wouldn’t pose such a big obstacle. And even though this hardware creates the slowest Regal, the AWD version still covers 0 to 60 mph in 6.8 seconds. Not bad!
Beyond the advanced drivetrain, the Regal offers a comfortable and rather plush cabin with dual-zone climate system, eight-inch touchscreen, and heated front seats, all standard. The standard and available safety systems make for a secure environment, although the smaller Verano actually has more air bags, if you like that sort of thing. And then there’s the infotainment system that supports up to ten devices and reads incoming text messages over the audio speakers. When we hear the name Regal, we still think of velour upholstery and Donna Summer playing on the radio. You can still get the latter—maybe streaming wirelessly through an app is the most immediate way—but otherwise the 2015 Regal reflects just how much tastes have changed since those velour days.

title: 4 Reasons to Keep Using Real Maps
subTitle: The folding map still has an important place in your driving life, the same way CDs haven't replaced vinyl records.
promoTitle: 4 Reasons to Keep Using Real Maps
promoTeaserSmall: The folding map still has a place in your driving life, just as CDs haven't replaced vinyl.
promoTeaser: The folding map still has a place in your driving life, just as CDs haven't replaced vinyl.
keywords: 4 Reasons to Keep Using Real Maps
metaTitle: 4 Reasons to Keep Using Real Maps
metaDescription: The folding map still has a place in your driving life, just as CDs haven't replaced vinyl.

pageElements.text: GPS and in-car navigation systems just may be the greatest thing added to cars since power steering. With them, your car can turn you into a dot on a moving map and smoothly direct you to any destination. No more wandering around, getting lost and squinting at dimly lit road signs; no more stopping at a gas station to ask directions. With an in-car navigation system, you are centered, directed, taken care of. Really, we are big fans of electronic map technology.
So why aren’t we suggesting you ask your GPS for directions to the nearest recycling center to throw away all your maps and atlases?

Because maps can still have a very important place in your driving life, if you’ll let them. You don’t have to give them up, since they are a packable, foldable supplement to whatever electronic mapping you have on board.
Here are our top four reasons to keep maps in your home, in your car, and in your trip-planning arsenal.
It’s tempting to beetle along, letting the GPS tell you what highway exit to take, but especially on a longer road trip, you’ll miss the larger sense of where you are.

1. No screen can replace maps’ ability to show the big picture. One of the frustrating things about a touchscreen navigation system is that you can’t easily zoom out and see, for example, the whole state of Maine or the whole Southwest, at least not while you’re driving. It’s tempting to beetle along, letting the GPS tell you what highway exit to take, but especially on a longer road trip, you’ll be missing a larger sense of where you are. This is even more important when you’re in the planning stages for a drive of more than a couple hundred miles. Open up a real paper map or atlas. At least look at a big-picture view online. But don’t overlook the satisfaction of marking out a route on a folding paper map with a highlighter; it never gets old.

2. Maps let you discover the unexpected detour and the interesting side road. Jack Kerouac didn’t have GPS. William Least Heat-Moon didn’t have a nav system. You may not have an itch to wander the blue highways and dives of the countryside the way they did, but when you’re traveling, you’re missing out if you ignore all possible paths to adventure. A paper map or road atlas makes these easier to spot because you aren’t laser focused on the quickest route to your destination. You know how the saying goes: not all who wander are lost.

3. Maps make you and your carmates work as a collaborative team. Remember the good old days of your parents fighting over which highway exit to take, while one angrily gripped the steering wheel and the other wrestled with a map? Well, you have GPS and a smartphone now, so you can enjoy navigating without all that stress. It can actually be fun now to let your passenger navigate with a map, since the outcome of the trip doesn’t absolutely depend on his or her map-reading prowess.

If your passengers are children, it can be incredibly educational to put them in charge of reading maps, and looking at the map to track your progress will keep them invested in the adventure of the trip (and they’ll spend less time asking, “Are we there yet?"). Often, maps have information that’s fun to read: things like the state bird, locations of museums and landmarks, and trivia about the region. Bonus: You can teach your kids how to fold a map correctly. Hours of fun!

4. Maps can be a memento of a great drive. You can’t frame your Google Maps link or your nav screen as a souvenir, but if you’ve taken a particularly memorable vacation trip, you can keep the physical evidence in the form of a map with your route marked on it. Someday people will come back to maps as a desirable alternative to screens, the way music lovers are coming back to vinyl records as a desirable alternative to CDs. There’s something so real about them.

Hard-edged and uncompromising, the Alfa Romeo 4C rasps and roars for a highly involving driving experience. It’s like a motorcycle with four wheels. With a short wheelbase, wide stance, and near 50/50 weight distribution, it takes corners like a Black Friday shopper careening into the electronics department. The turbocharged direct-injection four-cylinder engine is situated in the middle, just behind the cockpit, and will push the lightweight coupe from 0 to 60 mph in less than 5.0 seconds and on to a maximum speed of 160 mph. The driver can manually operate the transmission with shift paddles or let it change gears automatically. Steering lacks power assist; this is touted as a feature (there’s more feedback, although much more effort is required at low speed). Selecting the driving mode helps the coupe behave in bad weather or misbehave on the racetrack, with normal and sportier settings in between.

The 4C is all about sport, and you wouldn’t choose it over your SUV for a trip to the market, as there’s virtually no cargo capacity or interior storage space. Alfa Romeo chose the 4C to spearhead its return this year to the United States in order to emphasize the brand’s sporting heritage, with several more models promised in the coming years. The Mulsanne is the largest and most expensive of the Bentley lineup, and, yes, it is most often seen with a liveried driver wearing a chauffeur’s cap behind the wheel. The Mulsanne caters to a limited audience, and it’s not just because of the $300,000 price. Available in either a four- or five-seat configuration, the Flying Spur is more than adequately powered by either a 626-horsepower 6.0-liter twin-turbo W-12 engine or a slightly more modest 500-hp 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8. Setting the standard for luxury is bespoke, or custom, everything in the coupe. The buyer is presented with a seemingly infinite ways to outfit the Continental's interior and exterior: “hides” in fifteen different colors, seven real wood veneers, metal interior trims, and 120 exterior paint colors. And that’s just the standard set of choices. Everything you see and touch oozes money, including the Breitling-designed instrument panel and clock, the lamb's-wool floor mats, and the diamond-patterned quilted seats. But it’s not just about looking cool; the Continental is the quintessential grand tourer, meant to be driven on long stretches for long distances. There are five engine options, including a 626-horsepower W12 which, in a nod to the EPA, now shuts down six of its cylinders when they're not needed to improve fuel economy. All are paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. There may be cars that are sportier and better suited for the track, but they’re not as handcrafted as the GT.

Revised exterior, new 21-inch wheel option, new exterior color options, and the racing-car-based GT3-R model.

pageElements.text: What’s summer without at least one Thelma and Louise style road-trip adventure? Exactly! If you have a car, and you like that car, the pull of the road becomes irresistible when school lets out and the weather starts to sweat. Don’t wait till you’ve shot a bad guy and need to hit the road. A little planning can help you avoid the sort of place where self-defense is a necessary part of your road-trip agenda. If you have a smartphone—and we know you do—load it with a few necessary apps, and your road trip will not end in a blaze of fatalistic glory or car chases. (Though we were unable to find one that would help you locate a hitchhiking Brad Pitt. Sorry.)

1. TripIt (iOS, Android, BlackBerry, Windows Mobile)

Where is that hotel confirmation code? What did you do with the amusement park tickets? Just stop. Get this app, forward all your travel plans to the email address it gives you, and you'll know where they are. They're right there in your hand, since you are probably holding your phone. It orders everything into an itinerary and will even track the plans of other people you plan to meet up with along the way.

2. Field Trip (iOS, Android)

When you land in a town, you don’t want to see the museum everyone has seen. You want that out-of-the-way landmark, art project, or strange historical oddity. And you want to already know about it, not spend hours Googling to know about it. Yep. Us too. Get this app. When you go near a place, it will pop up all that crazy, detailed, offbeat data you want so you can really explore, or just pontificate. (It includes, among other sources, the eclectic reviews of Atlas Obscura.)

3. Roadtrippers (iOS, Android)

Be in the know before you get there. Tell this handy app where you are going, and it will suggest activities at your destination and along the way. Where to eat? What to do? You don’t have to search or ask anything, if you don’t want to; Roadtrippers will pop up suggestions based on where you are. You can also search a location while planning your trip, with categories for Hotels, Attractions, Natural Wonders, and Weird Stuff.

4. Trip Advisor (iOS, Android, Windows Mobile)

Wherever you plan to go, someone has been there. So skip the marketing copy and ask the people what their experience—of restaurants, hotels, destinations—was like. They will tell you the good, the bad, and the ugly. And you can book hotels, and usually save money, right through Trip Advisor.

5. Glympse (iOS, Android, Windows Mobile)

Meeting up with people? Got people who worry? Glympse will sort that all for you. Send them a Glympse from this app, and they can follow along where you are in real time. (With amazing accuracy.) So you can find each other easily, or Grandma can see that you arrived safely. The Glympse expires after the time you set, so it’s not like you are telling Granny what you do all the time.

6. HotelTonight (iOS, Android, Windows Mobile)

Sometimes, even if you planned your trip ahead of time, you don’t want to plan everything. You want to drive and stop when you are ready. The old way, you’d be limited to whatever hotel happened to be handy—and whatever price they wanted to charge you. With this app, you get to pick exactly the hotel you want from those that are nearby—and pay a low price. The catch? You have to wait till the last minute. The same day is good. The same day after 3 p.m.? Even better. Hotels release rooms they haven’t filled yet, right down to the wire, and you snap them up at rock-bottom prices.

7. KOA Camping (iOS, Android)

If you are traveling with a crew, piling into hotel rooms or renting more than one room can get old fast. If you don't have a camper of your own, you can still look to KOA. It offers some big, roomy cabins in many locations. And those cabins, or Airstreams, or other offbeat accommodations, are often cheaper than a hotel yet come with all the amenities of a hotel and lots more room for all your people to sleep. So how do you know if there is a KOA near where you are or where you are going? And if that KOA has cabins? This app. Get it.

Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle

This car: $40,675 (including destination )

You might also be considering: 2016 Acura RDX ($36,190); 2015 Cadillac SRX ($38,600); 2015 Infiniti QX50 ($35,995) (all prices include destination charges)

The compact-sport-utility party has been raging for a couple of years now and shows no signs of abating, right on through 2020. Entry-level, hybrid, family-friendly, high-performance, luxurious, odd-looking—whatever your little heart may desire, you can find it. It’s a buyer’s market, no doubt.

This has not been helping the frayed nerves of Lincoln dealers who have been waiting (not so patiently) for brand-new vehicles to fill the showrooms after Ford deep-sixed Mercury in 2011 and left the cupboards bare. Slowly and perhaps a tad too conservatively, Lincoln has refreshed, redesigned, and relaunched six vehicles, four of which are crossovers or sport-utility vehicles.

The Lincoln home page has a big fat tab labeled FUTURE VEHICLES. Until the 2016 MKX and Continental concept pop out of that folder and into dealerships, the 2015 MKC luxury compact crossover remains the news.
There are less expensive, more performance-oriented, more luxurious models, which makes it all the harder to be heard. Still, the all-new MKC has come bringing presents.

This is one tough category in which to trumpet your claim as the new, improved Lincoln. You can be all the New! and Improved! you want and still find you need to elbow your way into the crowd. There are less expensive, more performance-oriented, and more luxurious models, which makes it all the harder to be heard. Still, the all-new MKC has come bringing presents.

The Good:

Exterior design. The MKC cuts a fine figure, one of the most striking in the category, with the Mazda CX-5 and the Volvo XC60 its strongest competitors in terms of looks. It’s the best use yet of the Lincoln winged grille, which disappears altogether on the truly exciting Lincoln Continental Concept unveiled at the 2015 New York Auto Show. The MKC grille takes your eye along the leading edge of the hood, across its Angry Bird headlamps and straight into a deeply creased shoulder line that disappears and reappears as it passes the rear wheel. The doors have a deep concavity that is anchored by a lower sill between front and rear wheel wells, and tied visually to the front end’s lower grille. No matter where you’re standing, the MKC will catch your eye. In a good way.

Gorgeous leather. Although it was hard at night to actually see in our test car’s unrelenting black interior, the stitching is superb. Especially striking are the crossing arc patterns on the door inserts. Without the $1,700 panoramic sunroof, it would be difficult to see in daylight, too. I’d recommend Lincoln’s chic blend of Cream leather with Hazelnut or Ganache Truffle trim instead of boring black. Actually, I’d prefer to eat a box of creamy hazelnut ganache truffles.

Fashion sense. If you question your own, the Lincoln configurator offers the Black Label option, giving you four thematic scenarios: Oasis, Indulgence, Modern Heritage, and Center Stage. (I wouldn’t tell anyone that I used it.) Center Stage comes closest to the feel of our test car, although the Black Label interiors are a generous step above in quality of materials and saturation of color, in keeping with its extra large price tag. Yes, the Black Label’s all-in price of $47,100 kind of grabs you in the throat, doesn’t it? But the long list of included features is outstanding, and Black Label member privileges include premium maintenance, annual vehicle detailing, “anytime” car wash, and remote service pickup and delivery.

Rides like a dream. It certainly helps that our MKC had among its four optional items a control damping suspension worth every one of its $650. It rode like a magic carpet, turned on a dime, and behaved like you’d want all crossovers to behave—like a luxury car.

Technology. The basic MKC comes with a rearview camera. Whenever the newest and most sophisticated safety technologies are available, I say buy them. Blind spot monitoring with cross-traffic alert is the most important part of our car’s Select Plus package, priced at $1,100. I would add the Technology package ($2,295) to get adaptive cruise control with collision warning and brake support. Then there are forward sensing and lane keeping assist, just to remind you that someday, you won’t have to drive at all. Active park assist is also included in the Technology package. It’s brilliant; if you haven’t tried it, you should. Truly magic.

The Decent:

Efficient engines. My tester had the base engine, a turbocharged 2.0-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder with six-speed automatic transmission. It makes an adequate 240 horsepower with no drama, but the optional 2.3-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder’s extra 45 horsepower would certainly brighten any MKC owner’s day. The more powerful engine comes with all-wheel drive as part of the $7,045 upcharge over the front-wheel-drive 2.0-liter MKC, and fuel economy drops a tiny bit.

Push-button transmission. Between the right side of the instrument panel and the center console is a vertical row of large push buttons. That would be your push-button start/stop, followed by the transmission gear selector buttons. The very idea of this gear selector was controversial in our offices, but I got used to it quickly. The start-stop button began life at the bottom of the stack until it was discovered that drivers were pushing it by mistake while shifting. The MKC was recalled by Ford to reposition start/stop, which is now at the top where it belongs.

The Not So Much:

Black as an interior color. It’s impossible to see anything when everything is black. Why would anyone but a livery driver spec out a car this way when there are really tasteful combinations of cream and browns to blend with several choices of woods, including open-pore veneers? The black-striped, open-pore wood trim in our test car hinted at what is possible to find in the Lincoln interior design book. (Let the aforementioned Black Label option guide you.)

Sync is not winning any awards. After its multiple updates to make it work better, the Ford Sync infotainment system is now drab to look at. It’s easier to use, but with a recalcitrant phone operator that couldn’t decipher my Midwest twang and refused to make any calls for me unless I barked out the actual phone number, one digit at a time. My husband’s cell phone number is the only one I know by heart.
Matthew McConaughey. You can watch the incongruous MKC ads starring this once-respected actor at www.lincoln.com. You can find the pitch-perfect Ellen DeGeneres sendup here.

The Verdict:

The MKC takes Lincoln much closer to its goal of being the life of the luxury party. Designers have broken whatever fog they’ve been in, delivering stronger, more modern shapes and impressive interiors. Materials are first rate, and safety technology is a leading story. Rethink Sync, and we’ll break out the good champagne.

This is the car of the future. Except it’s here now. Although Chevrolet has comprehensively overhauled this car for the 2016 model year, there's still a lot to recommend the current model. Plug it in to charge it. Also? Fill the gas tank. Then go about about your daily business. If the charge runs low, the car will seamlessly switch to gas. But, unless you take some serious road trips, you may go months between visits to the gas station. Because the Volt can go up to 38 miles before switching to gas. In fact, it can go 380 miles with a full charge and a full tank of gas. And Chevy claims that Volt owners who charge regularly go 900 miles (on average) between fillups.

The cockpit-inspired dash has two seven-inch color LCD screens—one behind the steering wheel and the other in the center dash. The former feeds the driver information such as speed, range, and navigation, while the latter displays efficiency feedback, the (optional) rearview camera, and entertainment options.

The interior is attractive in a spaceship sort of way. There are four bucket seats with a console separating each, front and rear, meaning it's no family car, although the rear seats fold down to increase cargo space. Chevrolet MyLink radio lets you listen to Pandora, Stitcher, or whatever Internet radio you love. Siri Eyes Free lets you control your compatible iPhone through voice commands so your eyes stay on the road. The OnStar RemoteLink mobile app lets you check your battery status and lock or unlock the doors from your phone.

New for 2015

A larger battery capacity, 4G LTE connectivity with Wi-Fi hot spot, and a new exterior color.

Available all-wheel drive makes it sure-footed, and its compact footprint makes it easy to maneuver into tight parking spots and weave through traffic in town. The front passenger seats folds out of the way so you can carry a surfboard or an eight-foot ladder, and there are sixteen storage compartments and 48.4 cubic feet of cargo space with seats folded.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: My strategy for a road trip may be totally different from yours, but it works for me.

Having done my share of big drives, I’ve found 500 to 600 miles per day is about right for a pleasant experience, especially among a group. My goal is to exceed the daily average distance managed in North Africa by George Patton’s infantry without even contemplating the circuit record of 3,362 miles in the 24 Hours of Le Mans, set in 2010 by Audi.  Of course, it’s possible to go farther. But after any more than ten hours in even the greatest car, each minute becomes increasingly unbearable.

Variables can affect my formula: speed limits, unwelcome weather events, seasonal daylight variations, and urban congestion or a blocked highway. But over the years the outline has held up well enough. Here are the basics:

1. Early departure.

An experienced road-tripper friend eats a large meal at the hotel (“Free breakfast included!”) and loads up with fruit and yogurt for the car. On the other hand, I fill the gas tank before sunrise and hit the highway with an energy bar. It’s possible to knock down more than 100 miles while there’s little traffic. Around 9 a.m., I stop for a real breakfast that doesn’t entail pseudo-eggs and semi-lethal coffee.

2. Two-hour blocks.

Most folks remain seated two hours for a movie. Why not the same in a car? At 70 mph, there’s another 140 miles behind you. Then, a stop—try to keep it under ten minutes—to use the restroom, stretch the legs, and someone please walk Fido. “It gives kids a chance to wake up from their electronic coma,” says AAA of Southern California spokesperson Marie Montgomery.

3. Minimal lunch break.

I try to avoid a dedicated lunch stop. Instead, pass around sandwiches, nuts, and fruit. (When alone in the car, my lunch is sometimes an early afternoon milkshake from a drive-through.) A big midday repast affects alertness.

4. Teamwork.

We’re all in this together, from packing bags to route planning. Whether it’s a group of friends or cohesive family unit, everyone shares the same brief. Forgo that superjumbo drink, because we’ll have a stop in forty minutes just for you, throwing the team goal out the window. Be like an astronaut and wait for the space station. Teamwork also includes switching drivers to keep everybody fresh.

5. Side trip.

Congratulations! As long as we’ve exercised self-discipline and made great progress (for example, clearing the large metro area on today’s route before rush hour), there’s twenty minutes available for a scenic overlook or roadside attraction. “Customize your route based on what’s around,” says Montgomery. “If it’s not too far out of the way, why not?”

6. Target locked.

Yes, the summer day is long. But I want to check in to the hotel, which was reserved in advance, by about 5:30 p.m. Doing so brings the opportunity to answer email or splash in the pool. My experienced road-tripper friend jokingly suggests affixing flank steaks to the radiator grille so dinner will be ready upon arrival. But most people prefer to gather for leisurely dining to compensate for the day’s deprivations.

Conclusion:

Following these points avoids the unpleasantness of dragging in well after dark, grimy and worn, like Patton’s army. By dividing the journey into manageable segments, even those who have physical issues or short attention spans can experience the pleasure of long-distance car travel.

pageElements.text: Rearview, or backup, cameras are becoming a standard feature on new cars, but not all rearview cameras are created equal. Honda’s multi-angle system is one of the most interesting because it gives drivers three camera angles to get a better look at what’s behind them.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) recently finalized regulations that go into effect in mid-2018. The new law will require a 10-foot-by-20-foot zone of visibility behind the vehicle. Honda has already met this challenge by equipping all 2015 vehicles with this technology as standard, and has taken it one step further with its versatile camera that can display one of three angles: normal, wide-view, and top-down.

When the rearview camera is activated, drivers can select a view on the touchscreen, as you see here. Normal is, well, normal and shows you what’s directly behind the vehicle. Wide-view (shown below) provides a more panoramic view to show approaching vehicles, and the top-down view displays the ground directly behind the bumper of your car, but not underneath the car. The purpose of three different angles is to let the driver choose the view that suits their need and preference, but is more necessarily better? To find out, I tested this feature on the 2015 Honda Civic.

I wasn’t immediately sold on this technology when I first tried it out. In my garage I practiced placing my daughter’s toys behind the car to see if some views were better suited than others for not running over tricycles and strollers, but they all seemed more or less adequate and enabled me to spot items as soon as I put the car in reverse. However, I warmed to the feature over time as I found different applications and found that each view had its uses.

Top-down view is in part designed to help with parallel parking. As a mostly suburban driver these days, I’m not exactly testing this feature all the time, but the top-down view came in handy as I was reversing along an embankment at the park and needed to make sure a wheel didn’t slip into the ditch. Later I learned that it’s also useful for backing into a parking space to get close to a wall without hitting it. Another benefit is that it enables a driver to aim better while hitching a trailer, Honda spokesperson Chris Martin explained to me, although I can’t imagine doing that often in a Civic.

Perhaps a better case for the multi-angle view is the wide angle. Cross-traffic alert is an optional advanced safety feature that alerts the driver to vehicles approaching from the left or right of the car, but the Civic I drove wasn’t equipped with it. But as I reversed out of my driveway, I had a wider view of the road and could see vehicles and pedestrians approaching that I might not have in normal view. So in a way, I had 50 percent of the feature but without the alert. Martin pointed out that cross-traffic alert uses radar to detect objects and actually alerts the driver, but he added that the wide view would enable me to see vehicles or pedestrians sooner and faster than otherwise, and when it comes to spotting bouncing balls and running pedestrians, every second counts.
